column10:
1 / Tadasana
Tada means a mountain. Sama means upright, straight, unmoved. Sthiti is standing still, steadiness. Tadasana therefore implies a pose where one stands firm and erect as a mountain. This is the basic standing pose. Technique: 1. Stand erect with the feet together, the heels and big toes touching each other. Rest the metatarsals on the floor and stretch all the toes flat. 2. Tighten the knees and pull the knee-caps up, contract the hips and pull up the muscles at the back of the thighs. 3. Keep the stomach in, chest forward, spine stretched up and the neck straight. 4. Do not bear the weight of the body either on the heels or the toes, but distribute it evenly on them both. 5. Ideally in Tadasana the arms are stretched over the head, but for convenience, one can keep them by the side of the thighs.

Improves standing posture, increases spinal elasticity, firms hips and abdomen, develops mental agility.

2 / Vrksasana
Vrksa means a tree. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. 2. Bend the right leg at the knee and place the right heel at the root of the left thigh. Rest the foot on the left thigh, toes pointing downwards. 3. Balance on the left leg. 4. Join the palms and raise the arms straight over the head. 5. Stay in the pose for a few seconds with deep breathing. Then lower the arms and straighten the right leg and stand again in Tadasana. 6. Repeat the pose by balancing on the right leg and placing the left heel at the root of the right thigh.

Tones leg muscles and develops balance.

3 / Uttihita Trikonasana
Utthita means extended, trikona a triangle. This is the extended triangle pose. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. 2. Inhale deeply and with a jump spread the legs apart sideways 3 to 3.5 feet. Raise the arms sideways, in line with the shoulders, palms facing down. 3. Turn the right foot sideways 90 degrees to the right. Turn the left foot slightly to the right, keeping the left leg stretched from the inside and tightened at the knee. 4. Exhale, bend the trunk sideways to the right, bringing the right palm near the right ankle. If possible, the right palm should rest completely on the floor. 5. Stretch the left arm up, bringing it in line with the right arm and shoulders. Gaze at the thumb of the extended left hand. 6. Stay in this position from half a minute to a minute, breathing deeply and evenly. Then inhale and return to position 2. 7. Repeat on the left side.
1. Stand in Tadasana. 2. Inhale deeply and with a jump spread the legs apart sideways 3 to 3.5 feet. Raise the arms sideways, in line with the shoulders, palms facing down. 3. Turn the right foot sideways 90 degrees to the right. Turn the left foot slightly to the right, keeping the left leg stretched from the inside and tightened at the knee. 4. Exhale, bend the trunk sideways to the right, bringing the right palm near the right ankle. If possible, the right palm should rest completely on the floor. 5. Stretch the left arm up, bringing it in line with the right arm and shoulders. Gaze at the thumb of the extended left hand. 6. Stay in this position from half a minute to a minute, breathing deeply and evenly. Then inhale and return to position 2. 7. Repeat on the left side.
Relieves backaches, tones legs, develops chest.

4 / Parivrtta Trikonasana
Parivrtta means revolved. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. With a jump, spread the legs apart sideways 3 to 3.5 feet. 2. Turn the right foot 90 degrees and the left foot 60 degrees to the right. 3. Exhale, rotate the trunk in the opposite direction (to the right) so that the left palm rests on the floor on the outer side of the right foot. 4. Stretch the right arm up, keeping it in line with the left. Gaze at the right thumb. 5. Stay for 30 seconds with normal breathing.
1. Stand in Tadasana. With a jump, spread the legs apart sideways 3 to 3.5 feet. 2. Turn the right foot 90 degrees and the left foot 60 degrees to the right. 3. Exhale, rotate the trunk in the opposite direction (to the right) so that the left palm rests on the floor on the outer side of the right foot. 4. Stretch the right arm up, keeping it in line with the left. Gaze at the right thumb. 5. Stay for 30 seconds with normal breathing.
Increases blood supply to lower spine, expansion of chest.

5 / Uttihita Parsvakonasana
Parsva means side, kona an angle. Extended lateral angle pose. Technique: 1. From Tadasana, jump legs 4 to 4.5 feet apart. 2. Turn the right foot 90 degrees right. Bend the right knee until the thigh is parallel to the floor and the shin is perpendicular. 3. Place the right palm on the floor by the outer side of the right foot. 4. Stretch the left arm over the left ear. Keep the chest, hips, and legs in one line. 5. Stay 30 to 60 seconds. Repeat on the other side.
1. From Tadasana, jump legs 4 to 4.5 feet apart. 2. Turn the right foot 90 degrees right. Bend the right knee until the thigh is parallel to the floor and the shin is perpendicular. 3. Place the right palm on the floor by the outer side of the right foot. 4. Stretch the left arm over the left ear. Keep the chest, hips, and legs in one line. 5. Stay 30 to 60 seconds. Repeat on the other side.
Reduces fat at waist, aids digestion, tones knees and thighs.

6 / Parivrtta Parsvakonasana
Revolved lateral angle pose. Technique: 1. From Tadasana, jump legs 4 to 4.5 feet apart. 2. Bend the right knee to 90 degrees. Exhale and rotate the trunk to the right, placing the left armpit over the outer right knee. Place the left palm on the floor. 3. Stretch the right arm over the right ear. Twist the spine and gaze up.
1. From Tadasana, jump legs 4 to 4.5 feet apart. 2. Bend the right knee to 90 degrees. Exhale and rotate the trunk to the right, placing the left armpit over the outer right knee. Place the left palm on the floor. 3. Stretch the right arm over the right ear. Twist the spine and gaze up.
Rejuvenates spine and abdominal organs, aids colon waste removal.

7 / Virabhadrasana I
Dedicated to the hero Virabhadra. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. Raise the arms over the head; join the palms. 2. Jump the legs 4 to 4.5 feet apart. 3. Turn to the right. Bend the right knee to a right angle. The left leg should be stretched and the knee kept locked. 4. Head up, gaze at the joined palms. Stay 20 to 30 seconds. Repeat on the left.
1. Stand in Tadasana. Raise the arms over the head; join the palms. 2. Jump the legs 4 to 4.5 feet apart. 3. Turn to the right. Bend the right knee to a right angle. The left leg should be stretched and the knee kept locked. 4. Head up, gaze at the joined palms. Stay 20 to 30 seconds. Repeat on the left.
Relieves shoulder/neck stiffness, tones ankles/knees.

8 / Virabhadrasana II
Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. Jump legs 4 to 4.5 feet apart. 2. Stretch arms sideways. 3. Turn right foot 90 degrees right. Bend right knee to 90 degrees. 4. Turn the face right and gaze at the right palm. Stay 20 to 30 seconds.
1. Stand in Tadasana. Jump legs 4 to 4.5 feet apart. 2. Stretch arms sideways. 3. Turn right foot 90 degrees right. Bend right knee to 90 degrees. 4. Turn the face right and gaze at the right palm. Stay 20 to 30 seconds.
Relieves leg cramps, brings elasticity to back.

9 / Virabhadrasana III
Technique: 1. Stand in Virabhadrasana I on the right side. 2. Exhale, bend the trunk forward and rest the chest on the right thigh. 3. Simultaneously lift the left leg and straighten the right leg. The body and left leg should be parallel to the floor. 4. Stay 20 seconds.
1. Stand in Virabhadrasana I on the right side. 2. Exhale, bend the trunk forward and rest the chest on the right thigh. 3. Simultaneously lift the left leg and straighten the right leg. The body and left leg should be parallel to the floor. 4. Stay 20 seconds.
Develops harmony and poise, provides vigor for runners.

10 / Ardha Chandrasana
Ardha means half, Chandra the moon. Technique: 1. Perform Utthita Trikonasana on the right side. 2. Place the right hand on the floor about a foot in front of the right foot. 3. Raise the left leg until it is parallel to the floor. Turn the chest to the left and balance. Stay 20 to 30 seconds.
1. Perform Utthita Trikonasana on the right side. 2. Place the right hand on the floor about a foot in front of the right foot. 3. Raise the left leg until it is parallel to the floor. Turn the chest to the left and balance. Stay 20 to 30 seconds.
Stronger knees, cures gastric troubles, tones lower spine.

11 / Uttithita Padangusthasana
Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. 2. Exhale, raise the right leg and catch the big toe with the right hand. 3. Stretch the leg forward and pull it up as high as possible. 4. Stay 20 seconds.
1. Stand in Tadasana. 2. Exhale, raise the right leg and catch the big toe with the right hand. 3. Stretch the leg forward and pull it up as high as possible. 4. Stay 20 seconds.
Makes leg muscles powerful, develops poise.

12 / Parsvottanasana
Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. Join the palms in Namaste behind the back. 2. Jump legs 3 to 3.5 feet apart. 3. Turn to the right. Exhale, bend forward and rest the head on the right knee. 4. Stay 20 to 30 seconds.
1. Stand in Tadasana. Join the palms in Namaste behind the back. 2. Jump legs 3 to 3.5 feet apart. 3. Turn to the right. Exhale, bend forward and rest the head on the right knee. 4. Stay 20 to 30 seconds.
Elasticizes hip joints and spine, tones abdominal organs.

13 / Prasarita Padotanasana I
Technique: 1. From Tadasana, hands on waist, jump legs 4.5 to 5 feet apart. 2. Exhale, place palms on the floor between the feet. 3. Inhale, make the back concave. 4. Exhale, rest the crown of the head on the floor.
1. From Tadasana, hands on waist, jump legs 4.5 to 5 feet apart. 2. Exhale, place palms on the floor between the feet. 3. Inhale, make the back concave. 4. Exhale, rest the crown of the head on the floor.
Brings blood to brain, increases digestive power.

14 / Prasarita Padotanasana II
This is an advanced movement of the earlier pose. Here the hands are placed on the waist instead of on the floor (Image 35), or are folded at the back as if one is doing ‘namaste’ behind the back (Image 36) as described intensified. Effects: In this pose the hamstring and abductor muscles are fully developed, while blood is made to flow to the trunk and the head. People who cannot do Sirsasana (Image 184) can benefit from this pose, which increases digestive powers.
No technique steps provided.
Fully develops hamstrings, beneficial for those who cannot do headstands.

15 / Parighasana
Parigha means a beam or bar used for shutting a gate. In this posture, the body resembles a cross beam used for locking a gate, hence the name of the pose. Technique: 1. Kneel on the floor with the ankles together. 2. Stretch the right leg sideways to the right and keep it in line with the trunk and the left knee. Turn the right foot sideways to the right, keeping the right leg stiff at the knee. 3. Extend the arms sideways with an inhalation. (Image 37.) Take two breaths. 4. Exhale, move the trunk and right arm down towards the extended right leg. (Image 38.) Rest the right forearm and wrist on the right shin and ankle respectively, the right palm facing up. The right ear will then rest on the right upper arm. Move the left arm over the head and touch the right palm with the left. The left ear will then touch the left upper arm. (Image 39) 5. Stay in this position from 30 to 60 seconds, breathing normally. 6. Inhale, move the trunk and arms back to position 3. Bend the right leg and kneel on the floor, keeping the ankles together again. 7. Repeat the pose on the other side, substituting right for left and vice versa. Stay in the pose on both the sides for the same time. Effects: In this posture the pelvic region is stretched. One side of the abdomen is extended while the other side is laterally flexed. This keeps the abdominal muscles and organs in condition and the skin around the abdomen will not sag but remain healthy. The sideways spinal movement will help persons suffering from stiff backs.
1. Kneel on the floor with the ankles together. 2. Stretch the right leg sideways to the right and keep it in line with the trunk and the left knee. Turn the right foot sideways to the right, keeping the right leg stiff at the knee. 3. Extend the arms sideways with an inhalation. (Image 37.) Take two breaths. 4. Exhale, move the trunk and right arm down towards the extended right leg. (Image 38.) Rest the right forearm and wrist on the right shin and ankle respectively, the right palm facing up. The right ear will then rest on the right upper arm. Move the left arm over the head and touch the right palm with the left. The left ear will then touch the left upper arm. (Image 39) 5. Stay in this position from 30 to 60 seconds, breathing normally. 6. Inhale, move the trunk and arms back to position 3. Bend the right leg and kneel on the floor, keeping the ankles together again. 7. Repeat the pose on the other side, substituting right for left and vice versa. Stay in the pose on both the sides for the same time. Effects: In this posture the pelvic region is stretched. One side of the abdomen is extended while the other side is laterally flexed. This keeps the abdominal muscles and organs in condition and the skin around the abdomen will not sag but remain healthy. The sideways spinal movement will help persons suffering from stiff backs.
Stretches pelvic region, prevents skin sagging around abdomen.

16 / Ustrasana
Ustra means a camel. Technique: 1. Kneel on the floor, keeping the thighs and feet together, toes pointing back and resting on the floor. 2. Rest the palms on the hips. Stretch the thighs, curve the spine back and extend the ribs. (Image 40) 3. Exhale, place the right palm over the right heel and the left palm over the left heel. If possible, place the palms on the soles of the feet. 4. Press the feet with the palms, throw the head back and push the spine towards the thighs, which should be kept perpendicular to the floor. 5. Contract the buttocks and stretch the dorsal and the coccyx regions of the spine still further, keeping the neck stretched back. (Image 41) 6. Remain in this position for about half a minute with normal breathing. 7. Release the hands one by one and rest them on the hips. (Image 40.) Then sit on the floor and relax. Effects: People with drooping shoulders and hunched backs will benefit by this asana. The whole spine is stretched back and is toned. This pose can be tried conveniently by the elderly and even by persons with spinal injury.
1. Kneel on the floor, keeping the thighs and feet together, toes pointing back and resting on the floor. 2. Rest the palms on the hips. Stretch the thighs, curve the spine back and extend the ribs. (Image 40) 3. Exhale, place the right palm over the right heel and the left palm over the left heel. If possible, place the palms on the soles of the feet. 4. Press the feet with the palms, throw the head back and push the spine towards the thighs, which should be kept perpendicular to the floor. 5. Contract the buttocks and stretch the dorsal and the coccyx regions of the spine still further, keeping the neck stretched back. (Image 41) 6. Remain in this position for about half a minute with normal breathing. 7. Release the hands one by one and rest them on the hips. (Image 40.) Then sit on the floor and relax. Effects: People with drooping shoulders and hunched backs will benefit by this asana. The whole spine is stretched back and is toned. This pose can be tried conveniently by the elderly and even by persons with spinal injury.
Tones spine, beneficial for drooping shoulders and hunched backs.

17 / Utkatasana
Utkata means powerful, fierce, uneven. This asana is like sitting on an imaginary chair. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana (Image 1), stretch the arms straight over the head and join the palms. (Image 12) 2. Exhale, bend the knees and lower the trunk till the thighs are parallel to the floor. (Image 42) 3. Do not stoop forward, but keep the chest as far back as possible and breathe normally. 4. Stay in the pose for a few seconds, 30 being sufficient. It is difficult to balance in this pose. 5. Inhale, straighten the legs (Image 12), lower the arms, come back to Tadasana (Image 1) and relax. Effects: The pose removes stiffness in the shoulders and corrects any minor deformities in the legs. The ankles become strong and the leg muscles develop evenly. The diaphragm is lifted up and this gives a gentle massage to the heart. The abdominal organs and the back are toned, and the chest is developed by being fully expanded. It is a beneficial pose for horsemen.
1. Stand in Tadasana (Image 1), stretch the arms straight over the head and join the palms. (Image 12) 2. Exhale, bend the knees and lower the trunk till the thighs are parallel to the floor. (Image 42) 3. Do not stoop forward, but keep the chest as far back as possible and breathe normally. 4. Stay in the pose for a few seconds, 30 being sufficient. It is difficult to balance in this pose. 5. Inhale, straighten the legs (Image 12), lower the arms, come back to Tadasana (Image 1) and relax. Effects: The pose removes stiffness in the shoulders and corrects any minor deformities in the legs. The ankles become strong and the leg muscles develop evenly. The diaphragm is lifted up and this gives a gentle massage to the heart. The abdominal organs and the back are toned, and the chest is developed by being fully expanded. It is a beneficial pose for horsemen.
Strengthens ankles, massages the heart via diaphragm.

18 / Padangusthasana
Pada means the foot. Angustha is the big toe. This posture is done by standing and catching the big toes. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1.) Spread the legs a foot apart. 2. Exhale, bend forward and hold the big toes between the thumbs and the first two fingers, so that the palms face each other. Hold them tight. (Image 43) 3. Keep the head up, stretch the diaphragm towards the chest and make the back as concave as possible. Instead of stretching down from the shoulders, bend forward from the pelvic region to get the concave shape of the back from the coccyx. 4. Keep the legs stiff and do not slacken the grip at the knees and toes. Stretch the shoulder-blades also. Take one or two breaths in this position. 5. Now exhale, and bring the head in between the knees by tightening the knees and pulling the toes without lifting them off the floor. (Image 44.) Remain in this pose for about 20 seconds, maintaining normal breathing. 6. Inhale, come to position 2 (Image 43), release the toes and stand up. Return to Tadasana. (Image 1)
1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1.) Spread the legs a foot apart. 2. Exhale, bend forward and hold the big toes between the thumbs and the first two fingers, so that the palms face each other. Hold them tight. (Image 43) 3. Keep the head up, stretch the diaphragm towards the chest and make the back as concave as possible. Instead of stretching down from the shoulders, bend forward from the pelvic region to get the concave shape of the back from the coccyx. 4. Keep the legs stiff and do not slacken the grip at the knees and toes. Stretch the shoulder-blades also. Take one or two breaths in this position. 5. Now exhale, and bring the head in between the knees by tightening the knees and pulling the toes without lifting them off the floor. (Image 44.) Remain in this pose for about 20 seconds, maintaining normal breathing. 6. Inhale, come to position 2 (Image 43), release the toes and stand up. Return to Tadasana. (Image 1)
Tones abdominal organs, makes leg muscles powerful.

19 / Padahasthasana
Pada means the foot. Hasta means the hand. This posture is done by bending forward and standing on one’s hands. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1.) Spread the legs a foot apart. 2. Exhale, bend forward and without bending the legs at the knees insert the hands under the feet so that the palms touch the soles. (Image 45) 3. Keep the head up and make the back as concave as possible. Do not slacken the grip at the knees and take a few breaths in this position. 4. Now exhale, and move the head in between the knees by bending the elbows and pulling the feet up from the palms. (Image 46.) Stay in the pose for about 20 seconds with normal breathing. 5. Inhale, raise the head and come back to position 2 (Image 45), with the head well up. Take two breaths. 6. Inhale, stand up and return to Tadasana. (Image 1). Effects of Padangusthasana and Padahastasana: The second asana is more strenuous than the first, but the effects of both are the same. The abdominal organs are toned and digestive juices increase, while the liver and spleen are activated. Slipped spinal discs can only be adjusted in the concave back position as in Images 43 and 45. Do not bring the head in between the knees if you have a displaced disc.
1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1.) Spread the legs a foot apart. 2. Exhale, bend forward and without bending the legs at the knees insert the hands under the feet so that the palms touch the soles. (Image 45) 3. Keep the head up and make the back as concave as possible. Do not slacken the grip at the knees and take a few breaths in this position. 4. Now exhale, and move the head in between the knees by bending the elbows and pulling the feet up from the palms. (Image 46.) Stay in the pose for about 20 seconds with normal breathing. 5. Inhale, raise the head and come back to position 2 (Image 45), with the head well up. Take two breaths. 6. Inhale, stand up and return to Tadasana. (Image 1). Effects of Padangusthasana and Padahastasana: The second asana is more strenuous than the first, but the effects of both are the same. The abdominal organs are toned and digestive juices increase, while the liver and spleen are activated. Slipped spinal discs can only be adjusted in the concave back position as in Images 43 and 45. Do not bring the head in between the knees if you have a displaced disc.
Increases digestive juices, activates liver and spleen.

20 / Uttanasana
Ut is a particle indicating deliberation, intensity. The verb tan means to stretch, extend, lengthen out. In this asana, the spine is given a deliberate and an intense stretch. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana (Image 1), keeping the knees tight. 2. Exhale, bend forward and place the fingers on the floor. Then place the palms on the floor by the side of the feet, behind the heels. Do not bend the legs at the knees. (Image 47) 3. Try to hold the head up and stretch the spine. Move the hips a little forward towards the head so as to bring the legs perpendicular to the floor. 4. Remain in this position and take two deep breaths. 5. Exhale, move the trunk closer to the legs and rest the head on the knees. (Image 48) 6. Do not slacken the grip at the knees, but pull the knee-caps well up. Hold this position for a minute with deep and even breathing. 7. Inhale and raise the head from the knees, but without lifting the palms from the floor. (Image 47) 8. After two breaths, take a deep inhalation, lift the hands from the floor and come back to Tadasana. (Image 1). Effects: This asana cures stomach pains and tones the liver, the spleen and the kidneys. It also relieves stomach pain during menstrual periods. The heart beats are slowed down and the spinal nerves rejuvenated. Any depression felt in the mind is removed if one holds the pose for two minutes or more. The posture is a boon to people who get excited quickly, as it soothes the brain cells.

Do not bend the legs at the knees. (Image 47) 3. Try to hold the head up and stretch the spine. Move the hips a little forward towards the head so as to bring the legs perpendicular to the floor. 4. Remain in this position and take two deep breaths. 5. Exhale, move the trunk closer to the legs and rest the head on the knees. (Image 48) 6. Do not slacken the grip at the knees, but pull the knee-caps well up. Hold this position for a minute with deep and even breathing. 7. Inhale and raise the head from the knees, but without lifting the palms from the floor. (Image 47) 8. After two breaths, take a deep inhalation, lift the hands from the floor and come back to Tadasana. (Image 1). Effects: This asana cures stomach pains and tones the liver, the spleen and the kidneys. It also relieves stomach pain during menstrual periods. The heart beats are slowed down and the spinal nerves rejuvenated. Any depression felt in the mind is removed if one holds the pose for two minutes or more. The posture is a boon to people who get excited quickly, as it soothes the brain cells.
Cures stomach pains, relieves menstrual pain, soothes brain cells.

21 / Urhdva Prasarita Ekapadasana
Urdhva means upright, above, high. Prasarita means extended, stretched out. Eka means one, pada means the foot. This posture is done by standing on one leg, bending forward and lifting the other leg high up. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1) 2. Exhale and bend the trunk forward. With the left hand catch the back of the right ankle. Rest the right hand on the floor by the side of the right foot and the head or the chin on the right knee. 3. Lift the left leg as high up in the air as possible. Tighten both knees. Keep the toes of the lifted leg pointed upwards. (Image 49) 4. Stay in the pose for about 20 seconds, with even breathing. Inhale, bring the left leg down to the ground and come back to Tadasana. (Image 1) 5. Repeat the pose on the other side. Effects: This asana tones the leg muscles and reduces fat around the hips.
1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1) 2. Exhale and bend the trunk forward. With the left hand catch the back of the right ankle. Rest the right hand on the floor by the side of the right foot and the head or the chin on the right knee. 3. Lift the left leg as high up in the air as possible. Tighten both knees. Keep the toes of the lifted leg pointed upwards. (Image 49) 4. Stay in the pose for about 20 seconds, with even breathing. Inhale, bring the left leg down to the ground and come back to Tadasana. (Image 1) 5. Repeat the pose on the other side. Effects: This asana tones the leg muscles and reduces fat around the hips.
Tones leg muscles, reduces hip fat.

22 / Ardha Baddha Padmottanasana
Ardha means half. Baddha means bound, restrained, caught, withheld. Padma is a lotus. Uttana is an intense stretch. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1) 2. Inhale, raise the right leg from the floor, bend the right knee and rest the sole of the right foot on the left thigh. 3. Hold the right foot with the left hand, bring the right arm around the back and catch hold of the big toe of the right foot with the thumb and the fore and middle fingers of the right hand. (Image 50) 4. Release the left hand. Exhale, bend the trunk forward, place the left hand on the floor by the left foot (Image 51), and keep the head up. Make the back as concave as possible. Take a few breaths. 5. Exhale, rest the head or the chin on the left knee. (Image 52) 6. If the whole left palm cannot be placed on the floor, start with the tips of the fingers, then gradually place the fingers and lastly the whole palm on the floor. Repeat on the other side. Effects: Stiffness of the knees is cured by this asana. As the abdominal organs are contracted, digestive powers increase and the peristaltic activity helps to eliminate toxin creating waste matter.
1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1) 2. Inhale, raise the right leg from the floor, bend the right knee and rest the sole of the right foot on the left thigh. 3. Hold the right foot with the left hand, bring the right arm around the back and catch hold of the big toe of the right foot with the thumb and the fore and middle fingers of the right hand. (Image 50) 4. Release the left hand. Exhale, bend the trunk forward, place the left hand on the floor by the left foot (Image 51), and keep the head up. Make the back as concave as possible. Take a few breaths. 5. Exhale, rest the head or the chin on the left knee. (Image 52) 6. If the whole left palm cannot be placed on the floor, start with the tips of the fingers, then gradually place the fingers and lastly the whole palm on the floor. Repeat on the other side. Effects: Stiffness of the knees is cured by this asana. As the abdominal organs are contracted, digestive powers increase and the peristaltic activity helps to eliminate toxin creating waste matter.
Cures knee stiffness, helps deep breathing.

23 / Garudasana
Garuda means an eagle. It is also the name of the king of birds. Garuda is represented as the vehicle of Visnu. Technique: 1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1.) Bend the right knee. 2. Bring the left leg over the right thigh above the right knee and rest the back of the left thigh on the front of the right thigh. 3. Then move the left foot behind the right calf so that the left shin touches the right calf and the left big toe hooks just above the inner side of the right ankle. 4. Bend the elbow and raise the arms to the level of the chest. Rest the right elbow on the front of the left upper arm near the elbow joint. Join the palms. (Image 56) 5. Remain in this position for a few seconds, say about 15 to 20 with deep breathing. Effects: This asana develops the ankles and removes stiffness in the shoulders. It is recommended for preventing cramps in the calf muscles.
1. Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1.) Bend the right knee. 2. Bring the left leg over the right thigh above the right knee and rest the back of the left thigh on the front of the right thigh. 3. Then move the left foot behind the right calf so that the left shin touches the right calf and the left big toe hooks just above the inner side of the right ankle. 4. Bend the elbow and raise the arms to the level of the chest. Rest the right elbow on the front of the left upper arm near the elbow joint. Join the palms. (Image 56) 5. Remain in this position for a few seconds, say about 15 to 20 with deep breathing. Effects: This asana develops the ankles and removes stiffness in the shoulders. It is recommended for preventing cramps in the calf muscles.
Removes shoulder stiffness, prevents leg cramps.

24 / Vatayanasana
Vatayana means a horse. The pose resembles a horse’s face hence the name. Technique: 1. Sit on the floor, and place the left foot at the root of the right thigh in half Padmasana. 2. Place the hands on the floor by the side of the hips. Exhale, raise the trunk off the floor and place the top of the left knee on the floor. Place the right foot near the bent left knee and keep the right thigh parallel to the floor. (Image 57) 3. Stretch the pelvis forward, keep the left thigh perpendicular to the floor, raise the hands, straighten the back and balance the body. 4. Bend the elbows and raise the arms to the level of the chest. Entwine the forearms around one another and join the palms. Hold this position for about 30 seconds with normal breathing. (Front view: Image 58. Side view: Image 59). Effects: In this pose the hip joints receive proper circulation of the blood and minor deformity in the hips and thighs is corrected. The pose is also good for stiffness in the sacroiliac region.
1. Sit on the floor, and place the left foot at the root of the right thigh in half Padmasana. 2. Place the hands on the floor by the side of the hips. Exhale, raise the trunk off the floor and place the top of the left knee on the floor. Place the right foot near the bent left knee and keep the right thigh parallel to the floor. (Image 57) 3. Stretch the pelvis forward, keep the left thigh perpendicular to the floor, raise the hands, straighten the back and balance the body. 4. Bend the elbows and raise the arms to the level of the chest. Entwine the forearms around one another and join the palms. Hold this position for about 30 seconds with normal breathing. (Front view: Image 58. Side view: Image 59). Effects: In this pose the hip joints receive proper circulation of the blood and minor deformity in the hips and thighs is corrected. The pose is also good for stiffness in the sacroiliac region.
Improves hip circulation, corrects minor hip deformities.

25 / Salabhasana
Salabha means a locust. The pose resembles that of a locust resting on the ground, hence the name. Technique: 1. Lie full length on the floor on the stomach, face downwards. Stretch the arms back. 2. Exhale, lift the head, chest and legs off the floor simultaneously as high as possible. Only the abdominal front portion of the body rests on the floor and bears the weight of the body. (Image 60) 3. Contract the buttocks and stretch the thigh muscles. Keep both legs fully extended and straight. 4. Stay in the position as long as you can with normal breathing. Effects: The pose aids digestion and relieves gastric troubles and flatulence. Since the spine is stretched back it becomes elastic and the pose relieves pain in the sacral and lumbar regions. Regular practice has benefited persons suffering from slipped discs.
1. Lie full length on the floor on the stomach, face downwards. Stretch the arms back. 2. Exhale, lift the head, chest and legs off the floor simultaneously as high as possible. Only the abdominal front portion of the body rests on the floor and bears the weight of the body. (Image 60) 3. Contract the buttocks and stretch the thigh muscles. Keep both legs fully extended and straight. 4. Stay in the position as long as you can with normal breathing. Effects: The pose aids digestion and relieves gastric troubles and flatulence. Since the spine is stretched back it becomes elastic and the pose relieves pain in the sacral and lumbar regions. Regular practice has benefited persons suffering from slipped discs.
Aids digestion, beneficial for slipped discs, tones bladder.

26 / Makarasana
Verse 40 of the second chapter of the Gheranda Samhita describes Makarasana: ‘Lie on the ground face down, the chest touching the earth and both legs stretched out: catch the head with the arms. This is the Crocodile Posture which increases bodily heat.’ It is a variation of Salabhasana.
No technique steps provided.
Increases bodily heat.

27 / Dhanurasana
Technique
Lie full length on the floor on the stomach, face downwards.

Exhale and bend the knees. Stretch the arms back and hold the left ankle with the left hand and the right ankle with the right hand. Take two breaths.

Now exhale completely and pull the legs up by raising the knees above the floor, and simultaneously lift the chest off the floor. The arms and hands act like a bow-string to tauten the body like a bent bow. (Image 63)

Lift up the head and pull it as far back as possible. Do not rest either the ribs or the pelvic bones on the floor. Only the abdomen bears the weight of the body on the floor.

In this posture the spine is stretched back. Elderly people do not normally do this, so their spines get rigid. This asana brings back elasticity to the spine and tones the abdominal organs. In my experience, persons suffering from slipped discs have obtained relief by the regular practice of Dhanurasana and Salabhasana (Image 60) without being forced to rest or to undergo surgical treatment.
Stretches the spine backward, restores spinal elasticity (preventing rigidity in elderly), tones abdominal organs, provides non-surgical relief for slipped discs.

28 / Parsva Dhanurasana
Parsva means sideways. In this variation of Dhanurasana, one performs the posture lying on one’s side. Technique: 1. Perform Dhanurasana. (Image 63) 2. Exhale, roll over to the right side and stretch the legs and chest. (Image 64) 3. Inhale and come to position 1. Then exhale, and roll over to the left side. (Image 65) 4. Stay on either side for the same length of time. Effects: The sideways roll in this posture massages the abdominal organs by pressing them against the floor.
1. Perform Dhanurasana. (Image 63) 2. Exhale, roll over to the right side and stretch the legs and chest. (Image 64) 3. Inhale and come to position 1. Then exhale, and roll over to the left side. (Image 65) 4. Stay on either side for the same length of time. Effects: The sideways roll in this posture massages the abdominal organs by pressing them against the floor.
Massages abdominal organs by pressing them against floor.

29 / Chaturanga Dandasana
Chatur means four. Anga means a limb or a part thereof. Danda means a staff. Lie flat on the floor, face down and take the weight of the body on the palms and toes, exhale and keep the body parallel to the floor, stiff as a staff. Technique: 1. Lie flat on the floor, face downwards. 2. Bend the elbows and place the palms by the side of the chest. Keep the feet about a foot apart. 3. With an exhalation, raise the whole body a few inches above the floor, balancing it on the hands and the toes. (Image 66.) 4. Then gradually extend the whole body forward so that the feet rest on the upper portion of the toes on the floor. (Image 67) 5. Stay in the pose for about 30 seconds with normal or deep breathing. Effects: The pose strengthens the arms and the wrists develop mobility and power. It also contracts and tones the abdominal organs.
1. Lie flat on the floor, face downwards. 2. Bend the elbows and place the palms by the side of the chest. Keep the feet about a foot apart. 3. With an exhalation, raise the whole body a few inches above the floor, balancing it on the hands and the toes. (Image 66.) 4. Then gradually extend the whole body forward so that the feet rest on the upper portion of the toes on the floor. (Image 67) 5. Stay in the pose for about 30 seconds with normal or deep breathing. Effects: The pose strengthens the arms and the wrists develop mobility and power. It also contracts and tones the abdominal organs.
Strengthens arms and wrists, tones abdominal organs.

30 / Nakrasana
Nakra means a crocodile. This posture consists of several dynamic movements resembling those of a crocodile stalking its prey. Technique: 1. Lie flat on the floor, face downwards. 2. Bend the elbows and place the palms by the side of the waist. 3. Exhale, raise the whole body a few inches above the floor. 4. Take a few breaths and with an exhalation lunge the whole body a foot forward, lifting the hands and feet simultaneously off the floor. (Images 69, 70 and 71.) 5. Repeat the forward lunges four or five times. 6. Now reverse the movements and jump back. Effects: This asana develops powerful wrists, throws off lethargy of the body and fatigue of the brain, rejuvenates the entire body.
1. Lie flat on the floor, face downwards. 2. Bend the elbows and place the palms by the side of the waist. 3. Exhale, raise the whole body a few inches above the floor. 4. Take a few breaths and with an exhalation lunge the whole body a foot forward, lifting the hands and feet simultaneously off the floor. (Images 69, 70 and 71.) 5. Repeat the forward lunges four or five times. 6. Now reverse the movements and jump back. Effects: This asana develops powerful wrists, throws off lethargy of the body and fatigue of the brain, rejuvenates the entire body.
Develops wrists, removes lethargy and brain fatigue.

31 / Bhujangasana I
Bhujanga means a serpent. In this posture, lift the body up from the trunk and throw the head back like a serpent about to strike. Technique: 1. Lie on the floor face downwards. Extend the legs, keeping the feet together. 2. Rest the palms by the side of the pelvic region. 3. Inhale, press the palms firmly on the floor and pull the trunk up. (Image 72.) 4. Inhale, lift the body up from the trunk until the pubis is in contact with the floor. (Image 73) 5. Contract the anus and the buttocks, tighten the thighs. 6. Maintain the pose for about 20 seconds. Effects: The posture is a panacea for an injured spine and in cases of slight displacement of spinal discs the practice of this pose replaces the discs in their original position. The spinal region is toned and the chest fully expanded.
1. Lie on the floor face downwards. Extend the legs, keeping the feet together. 2. Rest the palms by the side of the pelvic region. 3. Inhale, press the palms firmly on the floor and pull the trunk up. (Image 72.) 4. Inhale, lift the body up from the trunk until the pubis is in contact with the floor. (Image 73) 5. Contract the anus and the buttocks, tighten the thighs. 6. Maintain the pose for about 20 seconds. Effects: The posture is a panacea for an injured spine and in cases of slight displacement of spinal discs the practice of this pose replaces the discs in their original position. The spinal region is toned and the chest fully expanded.
Tones spine, replaces displaced discs, expands chest.

32 / Urdhva Mukha Svanasana
Urdhva Mukha means having the mouth upwards. Svana means a dog. Technique: 1. Lie on the floor on the stomach, face downwards. 2. Place the palms on the floor by the side of the waist. 3. Inhale, raise the head and trunk, stretch the arms completely and push the head and trunk as far back as possible, without resting the knees on the floor. 4. The weight of the body rests on the palms and toes only. (Image 74) 5. Stay in the pose from half a minute to a minute with deep breathing. Effects: The pose rejuvenates the spine and is specially recommended for people suffering from a stiff back. The movement is good for lumbago, sciatica and those suffering from slipped or prolapsed discs. The chest expansion makes the lungs gain elasticity.
1. Lie on the floor on the stomach, face downwards. 2. Place the palms on the floor by the side of the waist. 3. Inhale, raise the head and trunk, stretch the arms completely and push the head and trunk as far back as possible, without resting the knees on the floor. 4. The weight of the body rests on the palms and toes only. (Image 74) 5. Stay in the pose from half a minute to a minute with deep breathing. Effects: The pose rejuvenates the spine and is specially recommended for people suffering from a stiff back. The movement is good for lumbago, sciatica and those suffering from slipped or prolapsed discs. The chest expansion makes the lungs gain elasticity.
Cures backaches, sciatic pain, and expands lungs.

33 / Adho Mukha Svanasana
Adho Mukha means having the face downwards. Svana means a dog. Technique: 1. Lie full length on the floor on the stomach, face downwards. 2. Rest the palms by the side of the chest. 3. Exhale and raise the trunk from the floor. Straighten the arms, move the head inwards towards the feet and place the crown of the head on the floor. (Image 75) 4. Keep the legs stiff and do not bend the knees but press the heels down. (Image 76) 5. Stay in the pose for about a minute with deep breathing. Effects: When one is exhausted, a longer stay in this pose removes fatigue and brings back the lost energy. The pose relieves pain and stiffness in the heels and helps to soften calcaneal spurs. It strengthens the ankles and makes the legs shapely. The abdominal muscles are drawn towards the spine and strengthened. Persons suffering from high blood pressure can do this pose.
1. Lie full length on the floor on the stomach, face downwards. 2. Rest the palms by the side of the chest. 3. Exhale and raise the trunk from the floor. Straighten the arms, move the head inwards towards the feet and place the crown of the head on the floor. (Image 75) 4. Keep the legs stiff and do not bend the knees but press the heels down. (Image 76) 5. Stay in the pose for about a minute with deep breathing. Effects: When one is exhausted, a longer stay in this pose removes fatigue and brings back the lost energy. The pose relieves pain and stiffness in the heels and helps to soften calcaneal spurs. It strengthens the ankles and makes the legs shapely. The abdominal muscles are drawn towards the spine and strengthened. Persons suffering from high blood pressure can do this pose.
Removes fatigue, strengthens ankles, soothes brain cells.

34 / Paripurna Navasana
Paripiirna means entire or complete. The posture here resembles that of a boat with oars. Technique: 1. Sit on the floor with the legs stretched straight in front (Dandasana). 2. Exhale, recline the trunk slightly back and simultaneously raise the legs from the floor, keeping them stiff as a poker. Balance is maintained only on the buttocks. Angle 60 to 65 degrees. 3. Remove the hands from the floor and stretch the arms forward near the thighs. (Image 78) 4. Stay in the pose for half a minute. Effects: This asana gives relief to persons who feel a bloating sensation in the abdomen due to gas and also to those suffering from gastric complaints. It reduces fat around the waistline and tones the kidneys.
1. Sit on the floor with the legs stretched straight in front (Dandasana). 2. Exhale, recline the trunk slightly back and simultaneously raise the legs from the floor, keeping them stiff as a poker. Balance is maintained only on the buttocks. Angle 60 to 65 degrees. 3. Remove the hands from the floor and stretch the arms forward near the thighs. (Image 78) 4. Stay in the pose for half a minute. Effects: This asana gives relief to persons who feel a bloating sensation in the abdomen due to gas and also to those suffering from gastric complaints. It reduces fat around the waistline and tones the kidneys.
Relieves gas, reduces waist fat, tones kidneys.

35 / Dandasana
Danda = a staff or rod. Technique: 1. Sit on the floor with the legs stretched straight in front. Place the palms on the floor by the hips, the fingers pointing to the feet. Stretch the hands straight and keep the back erect. (Image 77)
1. Sit on the floor with the legs stretched straight in front. Place the palms on the floor by the hips, the fingers pointing to the feet. Stretch the hands straight and keep the back erect. (Image 77)
Improves posture, foundation for seated poses.

36 / Ardha Navasana
Ardha means half. Nava is a ship, boat or vessel. Technique: 1. Sit on the floor. Stretch the legs out in front. (Image 77) 2. Interlock the fingers and place them on the back of the head. 3. Exhale, recline the trunk back and simultaneously raise the legs from the floor. The balance rests on the buttocks. (Image 79) 4. Keep the legs at an angle of about 30 to 35 degrees from the floor. 5. Hold for 20 to 30 seconds. Do not hold the breath during this asana. Effects: In Paripirna Navasana the exercise is effective on the intestines; whereas, Ardha Navasana works on the liver, gall bladder and spleen. These asanas bring life and vigour to the back and enable us to grow old gracefully.
1. Sit on the floor. Stretch the legs out in front. (Image 77) 2. Interlock the fingers and place them on the back of the head. 3. Exhale, recline the trunk back and simultaneously raise the legs from the floor. The balance rests on the buttocks. (Image 79) 4. Keep the legs at an angle of about 30 to 35 degrees from the floor. 5. Hold for 20 to 30 seconds. Do not hold the breath during this asana. Effects: In Paripirna Navasana the exercise is effective on the intestines; whereas, Ardha Navasana works on the liver, gall bladder and spleen. These asanas bring life and vigour to the back and enable us to grow old gracefully.
Works on liver, gall bladder, and spleen; strengthens back.

37 / Gomukhasana
Go means a cow. Mukha means face. Gomukha means one whose face resembles a cow. Technique: 1. Sit on the floor. (Image 77) 2. Bend the left knee back and sit on the left foot. Place the right thigh over the left one. 3. Raise the left arm over the head, bend at the elbow and place the left palm below the nape of neck. Lower the right arm, bend at the elbow and raise the right forearm up behind the back. Clasp the hands. (Image 80 and 81) 4. Hold from 30 to 60 seconds. Effects: The pose cures cramp in the legs and makes the leg muscles elastic. The chest is well expanded and the back becomes erect. The shoulder joints move freely.
1. Sit on the floor. (Image 77) 2. Bend the left knee back and sit on the left foot. Place the right thigh over the left one. 3. Raise the left arm over the head, bend at the elbow and place the left palm below the nape of neck. Lower the right arm, bend at the elbow and raise the right forearm up behind the back. Clasp the hands. (Image 80 and 81) 4. Hold from 30 to 60 seconds. Effects: The pose cures cramp in the legs and makes the leg muscles elastic. The chest is well expanded and the back becomes erect. The shoulder joints move freely.
Cures leg cramps, expands chest, improves shoulder joints.

38 / Lolasana
Lola means tremulous, moving to and fro or dangling like an earring. Technique: 1. Sit on the floor. (Image 77) 2. Place palms on the floor by the side of the hips. 3. Bend the right knee, place right sole beneath left buttock. Sit on it. 4. Bend left knee, place left sole beneath right buttock. Sit on it. The feet will be crossed. (Image 82) 5. Exhale, raise the trunk and legs off the floor and balance on the hands. (Image 83.) Gently rock the trunk and legs forwards and backwards. Effects: This asana strengthens the wrists and hands, the muscles of the back and the abdominal organs.
1. Sit on the floor. (Image 77) 2. Place palms on the floor by the side of the hips. 3. Bend the right knee, place right sole beneath left buttock. Sit on it. 4. Bend left knee, place left sole beneath right buttock. Sit on it. The feet will be crossed. (Image 82) 5. Exhale, raise the trunk and legs off the floor and balance on the hands. (Image 83.) Gently rock the trunk and legs forwards and backwards. Effects: This asana strengthens the wrists and hands, the muscles of the back and the abdominal organs.
Strengthens wrists, back, and abdominal organs.

39 / Siddhasana
Siddha means a semi-divine being supposed to be of great purity. This asana purifies 72,000 nadis. Technique: 1. Sit on floor. (Image 77) 2. Bend left leg, place heel near perineum. 3. Bend right leg, place foot over left ankle, heel against pubic bone. 4. Stretch arms, rest back of hands on knees in Jnana Mudra. (Image 84) 5. Gaze at the tip of the nose. Effects: This posture keeps the pubic region healthy. It is one of the most relaxing of asanas. Recommended for meditation and pranayama. Tones the lower region of the spine and abdominal organs.
1. Sit on floor. (Image 77) 2. Bend left leg, place heel near perineum. 3. Bend right leg, place foot over left ankle, heel against pubic bone. 4. Stretch arms, rest back of hands on knees in Jnana Mudra. (Image 84) 5. Gaze at the tip of the nose. Effects: This posture keeps the pubic region healthy. It is one of the most relaxing of asanas. Recommended for meditation and pranayama. Tones the lower region of the spine and abdominal organs.
Purifies 72,000 nadis, ideal for meditation.

40 / Virasana
Vira means a hero, warrior. Technique: 1. Kneel on the floor. Spread the feet about 18 inches apart. 2. Rest the buttocks on the floor, inner side of each calf touching the outer side of its respective thigh. Keep back erect. (Image 89) 3. Interlock fingers and stretch arms straight over head, palms up. (Image 91) 4. Exhale, place palms on soles, bend forward and rest chin on knees. (Image 92). Effects: The pose cures rheumatic pains in the knees and gout, and is also good for flat feet. Can be done immediately after food and will relieve heaviness in the stomach.
1. Kneel on the floor. Spread the feet about 18 inches apart. 2. Rest the buttocks on the floor, inner side of each calf touching the outer side of its respective thigh. Keep back erect. (Image 89) 3. Interlock fingers and stretch arms straight over head, palms up. (Image 91) 4. Exhale, place palms on soles, bend forward and rest chin on knees. (Image 92). Effects: The pose cures rheumatic pains in the knees and gout, and is also good for flat feet. Can be done immediately after food and will relieve heaviness in the stomach.
Cures rheumatic pain in knees, gout, and flat feet.

41 / Supta Virasana
Supta means lying down. Technique: 1. Sit in Virasana. (Image 89) 2. Exhale, recline the trunk back and rest the elbows on the floor. (Image 93) 3. Rest the crown of the head on the floor (Image 94), then the back of the head and then the back. (Image 95.) Stretch the arms out straight. (Image 96). Effects: This asana stretches the abdominal organs and the pelvic region. People whose legs ache will get relief from holding this pose for 10 to 15 minutes. It can be done after meals.
1. Sit in Virasana. (Image 89) 2. Exhale, recline the trunk back and rest the elbows on the floor. (Image 93) 3. Rest the crown of the head on the floor (Image 94), then the back of the head and then the back. (Image 95.) Stretch the arms out straight. (Image 96). Effects: This asana stretches the abdominal organs and the pelvic region. People whose legs ache will get relief from holding this pose for 10 to 15 minutes. It can be done after meals.
Relieves aching legs, athlete recovery, aids digestion.

42 / Paryankasana
In it the body resembles a couch. Technique: 1. Sit in Virasana. 2. Exhale and recline on the back. Arch the back up and rest only the crown of the head on the floor. 3. Hold opposite elbows behind the head. (Image 97). Effects: The dorsal region is fully extended so that the lungs are well expanded. The thyroids and parathyroids are stimulated. Cannot be done immediately after a meal.
1. Sit in Virasana. 2. Exhale and recline on the back. Arch the back up and rest only the crown of the head on the floor. 3. Hold opposite elbows behind the head. (Image 97). Effects: The dorsal region is fully extended so that the lungs are well expanded. The thyroids and parathyroids are stimulated. Cannot be done immediately after a meal.
Stimulates thyroids, expands lungs.

43 / Bhekasana
Bheka means a frog. Also called Mandukasana. Technique: 1. Lie face down on stomach. 2. Exhale, bend knees, heels towards hips. Hold soles with hands. (Image 98). 3. Turn hands so palms touch upper part of feet, toes pointing to head. Push hands down. (Image 100). Effects: Abdominal organs benefit. Relieves pain in knee joints due to rheumatism. Cures flat feet. Relieves pain in heels.
1. Lie face down on stomach. 2. Exhale, bend knees, heels towards hips. Hold soles with hands. (Image 98). 3. Turn hands so palms touch upper part of feet, toes pointing to head. Push hands down. (Image 100). Effects: Abdominal organs benefit. Relieves pain in knee joints due to rheumatism. Cures flat feet. Relieves pain in heels.
Relieves knee pain, cures flat feet, tones abdomen.

44 / Baddha Konasana
Baddha means caught. In this posture, sit on the floor, widen thighs until knees touch floor. Indian cobbler seat. Technique: 1. Sit on floor. 2. Join soles and heels. Grip feet firmly. 3. Widen thighs, lower knees to floor. (Image 101). 4. Exhale, bend forward, rest chin on floor. (Image 102). Effects: Recommended for urinary disorders. Keeps kidneys, prostate and bladder healthy. Blessings to women; checks irregular periods and helps ovaries. Pregnant women will have much less pain during delivery.
1. Sit on floor. 2. Join soles and heels. Grip feet firmly. 3. Widen thighs, lower knees to floor. (Image 101). 4. Exhale, bend forward, rest chin on floor. (Image 102). Effects: Recommended for urinary disorders. Keeps kidneys, prostate and bladder healthy. Blessings to women; checks irregular periods and helps ovaries. Pregnant women will have much less pain during delivery.
Treats urinary disorders, blessing to women for delivery.

45 / Padmasana
Lotus posture. Technique: 1. Sit with legs straight. 2. Place right foot at root of left thigh, heel near navel. 3. Place left foot at root of right thigh, heel near navel. (Image 104). Effects: One of the most relaxing poses. Keeps mind attentive and alert. Good for curing stiffness in knees and ankles. Spine and abdominal organs are toned.
1. Sit with legs straight. 2. Place right foot at root of left thigh, heel near navel. 3. Place left foot at root of right thigh, heel near navel. (Image 104). Effects: One of the most relaxing poses. Keeps mind attentive and alert. Good for curing stiffness in knees and ankles. Spine and abdominal organs are toned.
Basic meditation pose, tones abdominal organs/spine.

46 / Sanmukhi Mudra
San means six, mukha means mouth. Closing up. Technique: 1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Raise hands to face. Thumbs on earholes. Fingers on eyelids. 3. Ring fingers press nostrils. 4. Little fingers on upper lip. (Image 106). Effects: The senses are turned inwards. Rhythm calms the mind. Prepares practitioner for Pratyahara.
1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Raise hands to face. Thumbs on earholes. Fingers on eyelids. 3. Ring fingers press nostrils. 4. Little fingers on upper lip. (Image 106). Effects: The senses are turned inwards. Rhythm calms the mind. Prepares practitioner for Pratyahara.
Turns senses inward, brings inner peace, prepares for Pratyahara.

47 / Parvatasana
Parvata means a mountain. Technique: 1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Interlock fingers, stretch hands vertically up over head. (Image 107). Effects: Relieves rheumatic pains and stiffness in shoulders. Chest expands fully.
1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Interlock fingers, stretch hands vertically up over head. (Image 107). Effects: Relieves rheumatic pains and stiffness in shoulders. Chest expands fully.
Relieves shoulder stiffness, expands chest.

48 / Tolasana
Tola means a pair of scales. Technique: 1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Place palms on floor by hips. Exhale, raise trunk and balance only on hands. (Image 108). Effects: Strengthens wrists, hands and abdominal walls.
1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Place palms on floor by hips. Exhale, raise trunk and balance only on hands. (Image 108). Effects: Strengthens wrists, hands and abdominal walls.
Strengthens wrists and abdominal walls.

49 / Simhasana I
Simha means a lion. Dedicated to Narasimha incarnation. Technique: 1. Sit on heels. 2. Palms on knees, spread fingers. 3. Open jaws wide, stretch tongue out towards chin. (Image 109). Effects: Cures foul breath and cleans the tongue. Recommended to stammerers.
1. Sit on heels. 2. Palms on knees, spread fingers. 3. Open jaws wide, stretch tongue out towards chin. (Image 109). Effects: Cures foul breath and cleans the tongue. Recommended to stammerers.
Cures foul breath, clears speech for stammerers.

50 / Simhasana II
Technique: 1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Place palms on floor, stand on knees, push pelvis to floor. 3. Open mouth, stretch tongue out. (Image 110). Effects: Exercises the liver and controls bile. Relieves a painful coccyx.
1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Place palms on floor, stand on knees, push pelvis to floor. 3. Open mouth, stretch tongue out. (Image 110). Effects: Exercises the liver and controls bile. Relieves a painful coccyx.
Exercises liver, controls bile, relieves coccyx pain.

51 / Matsyasana
Fish incarnation. Technique: 1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Lie flat on back. 3. Exhale, arch back, rest crown of head on floor. 4. Hold elbows with hands behind head. (Image 113). Effects: Dorsal region fully extended, chest expanded. Relieves inflamed and bleeding piles.
1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Lie flat on back. 3. Exhale, arch back, rest crown of head on floor. 4. Hold elbows with hands behind head. (Image 113). Effects: Dorsal region fully extended, chest expanded. Relieves inflamed and bleeding piles.
Full breathing, stimulates thyroids, relieves piles.

52 / Kukkutasana
Kukkuta means a cock. Technique: 1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Insert hands between thigh and calf near knees. 3. Exhale, raise body and balance on palms. (Image 115). Effects: Strengthens wrists and abdominal walls.
1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Insert hands between thigh and calf near knees. 3. Exhale, raise body and balance on palms. (Image 115). Effects: Strengthens wrists and abdominal walls.
Strengthens wrists and abdominal walls.

53 / Garbha Pindasana
Embryo in the womb. Technique: 1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Insert arms between thighs and calves. 3. Exhale, lift thighs, balance on coccyx and catch ears with fingers. (Image 116). Effects: Abdominal organs contracted completely. Blood circulates well around organs.
1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Insert arms between thighs and calves. 3. Exhale, lift thighs, balance on coccyx and catch ears with fingers. (Image 116). Effects: Abdominal organs contracted completely. Blood circulates well around organs.
Contracts abdominal organs, improves blood circulation.

54 / Goraksasana
Goraksa means a cowherd. Technique: 1. Perform Padmasana. 2. Stand with top part of knees on the floor. 3. Balance and fold hands in front of chest. (Image 117). Effects: Achieves sense of balance. Coccyx gets elasticity.
1. Perform Padmasana. 2. Stand with top part of knees on the floor. 3. Balance and fold hands in front of chest. (Image 117). Effects: Achieves sense of balance. Coccyx gets elasticity.
Develops balance, provides coccyx elasticity.

55 / Baddha Padmasana
Baddha means bound. Technique: 1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Exhale, swing arms behind back and catch the big toes. (Image 118). Effects: Expands the chest and increases range of shoulder movements.
1. Sit in Padmasana. 2. Exhale, swing arms behind back and catch the big toes. (Image 118). Effects: Expands the chest and increases range of shoulder movements.
Expands chest, increases shoulder mobility.

56 / Yoga Mudrasana
Continuation of Baddha Padmasana. Technique: Exhale, bend forward from hips and rest head on floor. (Image 120). Effects: Intensifies peristaltic activity and relieves constipation.
Exhale, bend forward from hips and rest head on floor. (Image 120). Effects: Intensifies peristaltic activity and relieves constipation.
Awakens Kundalini, relieves constipation.

57 / Supta Vajrasana
Lying thunderbolt. Technique: 1. Sit in Baddha Padmasana. 2. Exhale, raise knees and recline back on floor. 3. Arch chest and rest crown of head on floor. (Image 124). Effects: Dorsal region fully extended. Pelvic joints become elastic.

column11: 1. Remove constricting garments, belts, glasses, contact lenses, hearing aids, and so on. 2. Choose a clean, level place free from insects, noise, and unpleasant smells. Do not practice on a hard floor or an unyielding surface or on a soft mattress. 3. Savasana is performed lying down full length on the back on a blanket spread on the floor. Draw a straight line there to position the body correctly. 4. Sit on the drawn line with the knees drawn up and the feet together. 5. Gradually lower the back vertebra by vertebra along the drawn line on the floor or on the blanket. 6. Place the body accurately so that the middle of the spine lies exactly on the straight line drawn on the floor or blanket. 7. Press the feet on the floor; lift the hips as well as the sacroiliac region; and with your hands, move the flesh and the skin from the back of the waist down towards the buttocks. 8. First adjust the back of the body. Then adjust the head from the front. 9. Extend first one leg and then the other fully. Join both the heels and knees. The joined heels, knees, crotch, center of the coccyx, the spinal column, and base of the skull should rest exactly on the straight line. 10. Adjust the front of the body, keeping the center of the eyebrows, the bridge of the nose, chin, sternum, navel, and center of the pubis in line.

Finally, stretch and adjust the back of the neck so that it is centrally placed on the floor.

column10:
201 / Uddiyana Bandha

1. Stand in tadasana. 2. Spread the legs about a foot apart. 3. Stoop slightly forward with bent knees, spread the fingers and grip the middle of the thighs with the hands. 4. Bend the arms slightly at the elbows and lower the chin as far down as possible into jalandhara bandha. 5. Inhale deeply and then exhale quickly so that the air is expelled from the lungs in a rush. 6. Hold the breath without inhalation. 7. Pull the whole abdominal region back towards the spine and lift it upwards. 8. Never hollow the chest during uddiyana practice. 9. Raise the lumbar and dorsal spine forwards and upwards. 10. Squeeze the abdominal organs towards the spine and press them against it. 11. Maintain the abdominal grip, lift the hands from the thighs and rest them a little higher on the pelvic rim for still firmer contraction. 12. Straighten the back without loosening the abdominal grip, raising the chin up. 13. Hold the grip as long as you can from ten to fifteen seconds. 14. First relax the abdominal muscles without moving the chin and the head. 15. Allow the abdomen to return to its normal position. 16. Then inhale slowly. 17. Take a few breaths, then repeat the cycle in Paras (a) to (k) not more than six to eight times at a stretch.

It is said to be the lion that kills the elephant named death.
It is the best of bandhas, and he who constantly practices it, as taught by his guru, becomes young again.
It exercises the diaphragm.
Through uddiyana bandha the great bird prana is forced to fly up through the sushumna nadi, the main channel for the flow of nervous energy, which is situated inside the spinal column (merudanda).
column13:
When clarity is gained, doubts vanish, bringing illumination.
Silence in the body will bring about silence in the mind.
Each out-breath takes the sadhaka's mind towards his own self and purges his brain of all its tensions and activities.
The fluctuations of the mind and the intellect cease, the 'I' or ego disappears.
His being then gets merged in the Infinite (Paramatma).
Savasana provides an experience of unalloyed bliss.
The body is at rest as in deep sleep, the senses as in dream but the intellect alert and aware.
Complete serenity of the body is the first requisite, and it is the first sign of attaining spiritual tranquillity.
Exhalation is the best form of surrender by the sadhaka of his all - his breath, life, and soul to his Creator.

column10:
202. Nauli (Images 595 and 596)
The word Nauli is not found in standard dictionaries. Ullola meaning a large wave or surge, conveys some idea of the process of Nauli where the abdominal muscles and organs are made to move laterally and vertically in a surging motion. Nau means a boat and li to cling to, lie on, hide or cover. The pitching of a boat on a stormy sea conveys some idea of the process of Nauli.

Nauli is a kriya or process and not an asana. Care should be observed in its performance, otherwise the process leads to numerous diseases. It is not, therefore, recommended for the average practitioner. First master Uddiyana Bandha before attempting Nauli, which is described in the Gheranda Samhita under the name Lauliki.

Technique

Stand in Tadasana. (Image 1)

Spread the legs a foot apart, bend slightly at the knees and stoop forward.

Place the hands with the fingers spread wide on the thighs just above the knees.

Lower the head until the chin rests in the notch between the collar-bones on the top of the breast-bone.

Inhale deeply, then exhale quickly so that all the air is forced from the lungs in a rush.

Hold the breath (without any inhalation). Pull the whole abdominal region back towards the spine.

The area between the pelvic rim and the floating ribs on both sides of the abdomen should be made passive to create hollowness there. At the same time push the abdominal recti forward. (Image 595 front view; and Image 596 side view)

Maintain this position from 5 to 10 seconds, according to your capacity.

Relax the grip on the recti and go back to the position described in para. 6 above.

Relax the abdomen and inhale slowly.

Take a few deep breaths. Repeat the cycle in paras 1 to 10 above, six to eight times at a stretch only once every 24 hours.

Practise Nauli on an empty stomach after evacuating the bladder and bowels.

Effects The abdominal recti are strengthened. The other effects of Nauli are the same as those of Uddiyana Bandha.

203 / Ujjayi Pranayama
Technique

Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. (This is the Jalandhara Bandha.)

Stretch the arms out straight and rest the back of the wrists on the knees. Join the tips of the index fingers to the tips of the thumbs, keeping the other fingers extended. (This position or gesture of the hand is known as the Jñāna Mudra, the symbol or seal of knowledge. The index finger symbolises the individual soul and the thumb the Universal Soul. The union of the two symbolises knowledge.)

Close the eyes and look inwards. (Image 597)

Exhale completely.

Now the Ujjayi method of breathing begins.

Take a slow, deep steady breath through both nostrils. The passage of the incoming air is felt on the roof of the palate and makes a sibilant sound (sa). This sound should be heard.

Fill the lungs up to the brim. Care should be taken not to bloat the abdomen in the process of inhalation. (Observe this in all the types of Pranayama.) This filling up is called pūraka (inhalation).

The entire abdominal area from the pubes up to the breast-bone should be pulled back towards the spine.

Hold the breath for a second or two. This internal retention is called antara kumbhaka. Observe Mūla Bandha as described on p. 366.

Exhale slowly, deeply and steadily, until the lungs are completely empty. As you begin to exhale, keep your grip on the abdomen. After two or three seconds of exhalation, relax the diaphragm gradually and slowly. While exhaling the passage of the outgoing air should be felt on the roof of the palate. The brushing of the air on the palate should make an aspirate sound (ha). This exhalation is called rechaka.

Wait for a second before drawing a fresh breath. This waiting period is called bāhya kumbhaka.

The process described from para. 7 to para. 12 completes one cycle of Ujjayi Pranayama.

Repeat the cycles for 5 to 10 minutes keeping the eyes closed throughout.

Lie on the floor in Savasana. (Image 592)

Ujjayi Pranayama may be done without the Jalandhara Bandha even while walking or lying down. This is the only pranayama which can be done at all times of the day and night.

Effects Aerates the lungs, removes phlegm, gives endurance, soothes the nerves, and tones the entire system. When done without retention (kumbhaka) in a reclining position, it is beneficial for high blood pressure and coronary troubles.

Note:
column11: 1. Spread a blanket, folded lengthwise, on the floor. Over it, at the head and exactly in line with the edge, lay another blanket folded three or four times so that it fits the back of the head and trunk. 2. Lie flat on the back on the folded blanket, keeping the body in a straight line. Do not cave in the rib-cage. Close the eyes and lie quietly for a minute or two. 3. Cover the eyes with a soft cloth for quick relaxation of the facial muscles. 4. Breathe normally. Consciously observe and feel the flow of breath throughout. 5. As you breathe in, make sure that both lungs fill evenly. Feel the chest expand upwards and outwards. Synchronize the two movements. 6. Breathe out quietly, emptying the lungs evenly on both sides. Correct it if the lungs move unevenly. 7. Continue this way for ten minutes, keeping the eyes closed.
column12: If hardness is felt in the lungs, or tension in and around the temples or in the head, it is a sign that you are exceeding your capacity; if so, reduce the length of the internal retention. Constriction in the abdomen, pressure at the temples or gasping for air indicate that you have reached your capacity in external retention (bahya kumbhaka), in which case reduce the length of the retention. Never breathe in during uddiyana bandha, as this may make you gasp and strain the heart.
column13: Breath is received as a divine gift and should not be drawn in forcefully. Inhale with warmth, elation, and joy as if you are receiving the life force. Exhale with a sense of gratitude, silently expressing your humbleness as surrender to the Lord.

Make sure that both lungs fill evenly. 4. Listen to the sound attentively, and maintain its rhythm throughout. 5. Fill the lungs completely till the sound of inhalation becomes inaudible. 6. Deep inhalation tends to move the eye-balls up. Consciously draw them down and gaze into the lungs. 7. At the start of exhalation immobilize the diaphragm; then breathe out slowly but not deeply. Here the out-breath will be slightly longer than normal. 8. Continue in the same way for ten minutes; then relax.

Note:
column11: 1. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques given in Stage V and exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 2. Take a slow, deep, steady in-breath through the nose. 3. Listen to the sibilant sound of the breath. Control, adjust and synchronize its flow, tone and rhythm. The flow is controlled by the resonance of the sound and the tone by the flow. This is the key to success in pranayama. 4. Fill the lungs from the bottom to the top, right up to the collar-bones. Consciously try to channel the breath to the remotest parts of the lungs. 5. Be continuously aware of the inflow of breath. 6. As you breathe in, your body, lungs, brain and consciousness should be receptive rather than active. Breath is received as a divine gift and should not be drawn in forcefully. 7. Do not inflate the abdomen as you inhale. Keep the diaphragm below the ribs throughout. Observe this type of pranayama. If the diaphragm is lifted above the floating ribs, the abdomen gets inflated instead of the chest. 8. The movements described above are made by drawing the entire abdominal area from the pubis to the breastbone towards the spine and then up towards the head. This automatically massages the internal organs. 9. In deep inhalation, the inner intercostal muscles at the front are lifted up. Just before exhalation, there is a further lift of these muscles, which prepares one before breathing out. 10. Now begins the process of deep exhalation, in which the trunk and diaphragm play an active role. 11. Maintain the lift of the intercostal muscles along with that of the diaphragm and start exhalation. Allow the breath to go out slowly, deeply and steadily. 12. After a few seconds, the grip of the trunk relaxes by itself gradually until the lungs have been passively emptied. Maintain continuous awareness during the out-flow of breath. 13. This completes one cycle. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes keeping the eyes closed and the limbs relaxed. Inhale and then lie down and rest in Savasana. 14. Inhale with warmth, elation and joy as if you are receiving the life force. 15. Exhale with a sense of gratitude, silently expressing your humbleness as surrender to the Lord. 16. At each inhalation and exhalation there is a fractional pause when the muscles of the torso adjust themselves. Learn to be aware of this.

203 / Ujjayi Pranayama
Technique

Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. (This is the Jalandhara Bandha.)

Stretch the arms out straight and rest the back of the wrists on the knees. Join the tips of the index fingers to the tips of the thumbs, keeping the other fingers extended. (This position or gesture of the hand is known as the Jñāna Mudra, the symbol or seal of knowledge. The index finger symbolises the individual soul and the thumb the Universal Soul. The union of the two symbolises knowledge.)

Close the eyes and look inwards. (Image 597)

Exhale completely.

Now the Ujjayi method of breathing begins.

Take a slow, deep steady breath through both nostrils. The passage of the incoming air is felt on the roof of the palate and makes a sibilant sound (sa). This sound should be heard.

Fill the lungs up to the brim. Care should be taken not to bloat the abdomen in the process of inhalation. (Observe this in all the types of Pranayama.) This filling up is called pūraka (inhalation).

The entire abdominal area from the pubes up to the breast-bone should be pulled back towards the spine.

Hold the breath for a second or two. This internal retention is called antara kumbhaka. Observe Mūla Bandha as described on p. 366.

Exhale slowly, deeply and steadily, until the lungs are completely empty. As you begin to exhale, keep your grip on the abdomen. After two or three seconds of exhalation, relax the diaphragm gradually and slowly. While exhaling the passage of the outgoing air should be felt on the roof of the palate. The brushing of the air on the palate should make an aspirate sound (ha). This exhalation is called rechaka.

Wait for a second before drawing a fresh breath. This waiting period is called bāhya kumbhaka.

The process described from para. 7 to para. 12 completes one cycle of Ujjayi Pranayama.

Repeat the cycles for 5 to 10 minutes keeping the eyes closed throughout.

Lie on the floor in Savasana. (Image 592)

Ujjayi Pranayama may be done without the Jalandhara Bandha even while walking or lying down. This is the only pranayama which can be done at all times of the day and night.

Note:
column11: 1. Sit in any comfortable position following the techniques given in Stage V, and exhale. 2. Breathe in and hold the breath. Keep the trunk firm and alert. 3. Do not raise the bridge of the nose or the eyes or the head throughout retention. 4. Feel the breath percolating to the remotest pores of the skin of the torso and become aware of the process. 5. After a few seconds, this awareness begins to lose its grip. The moment this happens, exhale normally. This is one cycle. Practice ten to fifteen of them. 6. If any fatigue is felt during this practice, these cycles may be alternated with normal breathing. 7. When this practice becomes easy, intensify it until you can comfortably hold the breath for ten to fifteen seconds at a time. To increase the length of retention, lift the diaphragm towards the lungs, hold it firmly, and draw the abdomen in and up towards the spine. Then hold the breath without raising the bridge of the nose. 8. If hardness is felt in the lungs, or tension in and around the temples or in the head, it is a sign that you are exceeding your capacity; if so, reduce the length of the internal retention. 9. The transition from internal retention to exhalation should be smooth. 10. Breathe out slowly, without losing control of the trunk, diaphragm, and lungs. After completing the practice take a few deep breaths and then rest in savasana.
