column11: 1. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques described in Stage V, and exhale. 2. Take strong deep breaths without any force, jerk, or harshness, keeping the trunk alert. 3. Hold the breath for ten to fifteen seconds. 4. In a few moments, the body loses its grip. To maintain this grip, raise the side ribs. 5. Now contract the lower trunk from the pubis, perineum, and anus and lift it up towards the chest along with the spine. This is mula bandha. 6. This lift of the torso creates tension in the head. Lower the head from the base of the back of the neck. This gives better jalandhara bandha and relieves tension in the head. 7. Feel the breath percolating to the remotest pores of the skin of the torso, arousing awareness everywhere. 8. Keep the eyes, ears, and tongue passive, and the brain quiet. 9. If the duration of retention is too long, the throat feels strained and the facial muscles and temples become taut. This means that you are losing your grip. So, recharge the energy of the torso as instructed above. 10. If tension is still felt in the head and trunk and the face feels flushed, it means you are not maintaining the correct grip or have exceeded your capacity. This may lead to injury to the nervous system. In which case, do not continue the retention. 11. Breathe out normally and deeply without losing grip on the trunk. This is one cycle of retention. Practice ten to twelve such cycles, maintaining the same awareness throughout as in the first cycle. 12. Since the capacity for retention varies with individuals, it is not possible to mention the duration of breath retention. It is advisable to do internal retention after an interval of three or four breaths. 13. After completing the practice, inhale and lie in Savasana.

column11: This advanced stage combines internal (antara) and external (bahya) retentions (kumbhakas) with two or three in-and-out breaths. Technique: 1. Exhale: First, exhale completely. 2. Internal Retention: Breathe in deeply. After full inhalation, retain the breath (antara kumbhaka) for ten seconds. 3. External Retention: Breathe out deeply. After full exhalation, hold the breath (bahya kumbhaka) with uddiyana bandha for five seconds, then inhale deeply. This completes one cycle. 4. Recovery Breaths: Exhale, and take two or three deep in-and-out breaths. Then repeat the cycles of kumbhakas, followed again by two or three deep in-and-out breaths. 5. Duration: Do five to six cycles, ending with inhalation. Then lie down in savasana.

column10:
204 / Sūrya Bhedana Prānāyāma
Technique

Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. (This is Jalandhara Bandha.)

Stretch the left arm. Rest the back of the left wrist on the left knee. Perform Jñāna Mudra with the left hand (as stated in stage 3 of the technique of Ujjayi).

Bend the right arm at the elbow. Bend the index and middle fingers towards the palm, keeping them passive. Bring the ring and little fingers towards the thumb. (Image 598)

Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose just below the nasal bone, the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose just below the nasal bone, just above the curve of the fatty tissue of the nostrils above the upper jaw.

Press the ring and the little finger to block the left side of the nose completely.

With the right thumb, press the fatty tissue on the right side so as to make the outer edge of the right nostril parallel to the lower edge of the cartilage of the septum.

The right thumb is bent at the top joint and the tip of the thumb is placed at a right angle to the septum. (Image 599)

Now inhale slowly and deeply controlling the aperture of the right nostril with the tip of the thumb nearer the nail. Fill the lungs to the brim (pūraka).

Then block the right nostril so that both are now blocked.

Hold the breath for about 5 seconds (antara kumbhaka) while practising Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Keeping the right nostril completely blocked, open the left nostril partially and exhale through it slowly and deeply (rechaka).

During the exhalation regulate the rhythmic flow of air from the left nostril by adjusting pressure with the ring and little fingers, so that the outer edge of the left nostril is kept parallel to the septum. The pressure should be exerted from the inner sides of the tips of the fingers (away from the nails).

This completes one cycle of Sūrya Bhedana Prānāyāma. Continue with more cycles at a stretch from 5 to 10 minutes, according to capacity.

All the inhalations in Sūrya Bhedana are from the right nostril and all the exhalations from the left nostril.

Throughout the process, the passage of air is felt at the tips of the fingers and the thumbs and in the nasal membranes where pressure is applied. The passage of air makes a sound similar to air escaping from a cycle tube. This sound should be maintained constant throughout by varying pressure on the nostrils.

The eyes, temples, eyebrows and the skin on the forehead should remain completely passive and show no sign of strain.

The mind should be absorbed completely in listening to the proper sound of the passage of air and in maintaining a proper rhythm in breathing.

Each inhalation and exhalation should last for the same length of time.

The inhalation and the exhalation should not be forced. An even and slow rhythm should be maintained throughout.

Lie down in Savasana after completing pranayama. (Image 592)

Effects Increases digestive power, soothes and invigorates the nerves, and cleans the sinuses. Fills lungs more slowly and fully than Ujjayi. Beneficial for persons with low blood pressure.

Note: Those with high blood pressure or heart trouble should not perform breath retention (kumbhaka).
column11: 1. Sit in any asana following the techniques given in Paras of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Exhale deeply. 3. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 of Chapter 22 on digital pranayama. 4. Block the left nostril completely with the tips of the ring and little fingers, without disturbing the septum. 5. Partially close the right nostril with the right thumb, keeping the inner wall of the outer right nostril parallel to the septum. 6. Inhale slowly, carefully, and deeply through the partially closed right nostril, without using force, until the lungs are completely full. 7. Completely block the right nostril, without disturbing the septum. 8. Release the pressure on the left nostril and open it partially. 9. Exhale slowly, steadily, and deeply through the partially open left nostril, till the lungs feel empty. 10. This completes one cycle. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes, inhale with open nostrils, then lie in Savasana.

When this becomes stabilized without disturbing the flow and the smoothness of the in and out breaths, lengthen the duration of retention. 7. Now exhale slowly, steadily, and deeply through the partially opened left nostril, till the lungs feel completely empty. 8. This completes one cycle. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes, inhale with open nostrils, then lie in Savasana.

column10:
204 / Sūrya Bhedana Prānāyāma
Technique

Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. (This is Jalandhara Bandha.)

Stretch the left arm. Rest the back of the left wrist on the left knee. Perform Jñāna Mudra with the left hand (as stated in stage 3 of the technique of Ujjayi).

Bend the right arm at the elbow. Bend the index and middle fingers towards the palm, keeping them passive. Bring the ring and little fingers towards the thumb. (Image 598)

Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose just below the nasal bone, the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose just below the nasal bone, just above the curve of the fatty tissue of the nostrils above the upper jaw.

Press the ring and the little finger to block the left side of the nose completely.

With the right thumb, press the fatty tissue on the right side so as to make the outer edge of the right nostril parallel to the lower edge of the cartilage of the septum.

The right thumb is bent at the top joint and the tip of the thumb is placed at a right angle to the septum. (Image 599)

Now inhale slowly and deeply controlling the aperture of the right nostril with the tip of the thumb nearer the nail. Fill the lungs to the brim (pūraka).

Then block the right nostril so that both are now blocked.

Hold the breath for about 5 seconds (antara kumbhaka) while practising Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Keeping the right nostril completely blocked, open the left nostril partially and exhale through it slowly and deeply (rechaka).

During the exhalation regulate the rhythmic flow of air from the left nostril by adjusting pressure with the ring and little fingers, so that the outer edge of the left nostril is kept parallel to the septum. The pressure should be exerted from the inner sides of the tips of the fingers (away from the nails).

This completes one cycle of Sūrya Bhedana Prānāyāma. Continue with more cycles at a stretch from 5 to 10 minutes, according to capacity.

All the inhalations in Sūrya Bhedana are from the right nostril and all the exhalations from the left nostril.

Throughout the process, the passage of air is felt at the tips of the fingers and the thumbs and in the nasal membranes where pressure is applied. The passage of air makes a sound similar to air escaping from a cycle tube. This sound should be maintained constant throughout by varying pressure on the nostrils.

The eyes, temples, eyebrows and the skin on the forehead should remain completely passive and show no sign of strain.

The mind should be absorbed completely in listening to the proper sound of the passage of air and in maintaining a proper rhythm in breathing.

Each inhalation and exhalation should last for the same length of time.

The inhalation and the exhalation should not be forced. An even and slow rhythm should be maintained throughout.

Lie down in Savasana after completing pranayama. (Image 592)

Effects Increases digestive power, soothes and invigorates the nerves, and cleans the sinuses. Fills lungs more slowly and fully than Ujjayi. Beneficial for persons with low blood pressure.

Note: Those with high blood pressure or heart trouble should not perform breath retention (kumbhaka).
column11: 1. Sit in any asana, following the techniques of Paras 1 to 7 of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 3. Inhale through the right nostril, slowly, deeply, and fully, following the techniques of Paras 2, and of Stage II. 4. Completely block the right nostril, partially release the left and exhale through it slowly and deeply, following the techniques given in Paras and of Stage I. 5. When the lungs feel completely empty, block both the nostrils and do external retention with Uddiyana Bandha to your capacity without strain. 6. External retention takes longer to master than the internal one. Hence, gradually increase the duration of external retention by one or two seconds. 7. When this becomes stabilized, continue increasing the length of retention without disturbing the flow and the smoothness of the in and out breaths. 8. This completes one cycle. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes; inhale with open nostrils, then lie in Savasana.

column11: 1. Sit in any asana, following the techniques of Paras of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 3. Inhale, following the techniques given in Paras and 3 of Stage II, ending with Mula Bandha. 4. Then exhale, following the techniques given in Paras and III and ending with Uddiyana Bandha. 5. Do retentions at the end of each inhalation as well as each exhalation, starting with shorter retentions and gradually increasing their length as the lung capacity develops. 6. Do not exceed eight to ten seconds in Uddiyana Bandha. 7. This completes one cycle. Practice as many cycles as you comfortably can without strain, or for ten to fifteen minutes. Inhale with open nostrils, then lie in Savasana.

column10:
205 / Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma
Technique

Follow the technique given in paras 1 to 8 of Sūrya Bhedana Prānāyāma. (Image 599)

Empty the lungs completely through the right nostril. Control the aperture of the right nostril with the inner side of the right thumb, away from the nail.

Now inhale slowly, steadily and deeply through the right nostril, controlling the aperture with the tip of the right thumb near the nail. Fill the lungs to the brim (pūraka). During this inhalation the left nostril is completely blocked by the ring and little fingers.

After full inhalation, block the right nostril completely with the pressure of the thumb and release the pressure of the ring and little fingers on the left nostril. Readjust them on the outer edge of the left nostril and keep it parallel to the septum. Exhale slowly, steadily and deeply through the left nostril. Empty the lungs completely. The pressure should be exerted from the inner sides of the tips of the ring and little fingers (away from the nails) (rechaka).

After full exhalation through the left nostril, change the pressure on it by adjusting the fingers. In the changed position, the tips of the ring and little fingers nearer the nails exert the pressure.

Now inhale through the left nostril slowly, steadily and deeply, filling the lungs to the brim (pūraka).

After full inhalation through the left nostril, block it and exhale through the right nostril, adjusting the pressure of the right thumb on the right nostril as stated in para. 2 above (rechaka).

This completes one cycle of Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma. Here the rhythm of breathing is as follows: a. Exhale through the right nostril. b. Inhale through the right nostril. c. Exhale through the left nostril. d. Inhale through the left nostril. e. Exhale through the right nostril. f. Inhale through the right nostril. g. Exhale through the left nostril. h. Inhale through the left nostril. i. Exhale through the right nostril. j. Inhale through the right nostril ... and so on.

Stage (a) above is the preparatory one. The first real Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma cycle starts at stage (b) and ends at stage (e). The second cycle starts at stage (f) and ends at stage (i). Stage (j) is the safety measure to be observed after the completion of the cycles in order to prevent gasping, breathlessness and strain on the heart.

Do 8 to 10 cycles at a stretch as described above. This may take 6 or 8 minutes.

Inhalation and exhalation from each side should take the same time. In the beginning the duration will be unequal. Persevere until equality is achieved.

After achieving mastery over the equal duration and precision over inhalation and exhalation on either side an attempt may be made to retain breath (antara kumbhaka) after inhaling.

This precision is only achieved after long practice.

Retention should not disturb the rhythm and equality of inhalation and exhalation. If either are disturbed curtail the period of retention or hold the breath on alternate cycles.

During retention after inhalation practise Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Do not attempt to hold the breath after exhalation (bāhya kumbhaka, Image 600) until you have mastered retention after inhalation (antara kumbhaka). Then during bāhya kumbhaka practise Uddiyana (Images 593, 594) with Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Retention and the lengthening of inhalation and exhalation should only be attempted with the help and under the guidance of an experienced Guru.

Always conclude by lying down in Savasana. (Image 592)

Effects Increases oxygen supply to the blood, refreshing the body; calms and purifies the nerves; stills and clears the mind (lucidity).

Note: Persons with high blood pressure or heart trouble should not hold their breath (kumbhaka). Persons with low blood pressure benefit from internal retention.
column11: 1. Sit in any asana, following the techniques given in Paras 1 to 7 of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 of Chapter on digital pranayama and narrow both the nasal passages with the thumb, ring, and little fingers. 3. Exhale completely through the narrowly open, but controlled nostrils. 4. Now inhale, but do not disturb the width of the passages; keep the septum and the fingers stable to prevent the head from tilting. 5. Maintain an even flow of breath in both nostrils, synchronizing it with the movement of the chest. 6. The breath should be soft, slow, and smooth. Fill the lungs to the brim. 7. Then hold the breath for a second or two in order to adjust the fingers for exhalation. 8. Exhale softly, slowly, and smoothly, maintaining even rhythm. 9. Synchronize the flow of the exhalation with the release of the extension and expansion of the rib-cage. 10. As practice improves, narrow the passages more and more, so that the breath flows finer and finer. 11. The narrower the passages, the better the control of the breath. 12. One inhalation and one exhalation complete one cycle. 13. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes and end with an in-breath. 14. Lower the hand, raise the head, and then lie in Savasana.

column11: 1. Sit in any asana, following the techniques given in Paras of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 of Chapter 22 on digital pranayama. 3. Block the left nostril completely, without disturbing the septum or the passage on the right. 4. Narrow the right nostril, bringing its outer portion closer towards the septum, without disturbing the position of the nose. 5. Exhale through the right nostril. 6. Inhale through it slowly and steadily, without disturbing the width of its passage. 7. Keep the septum and the fingers stable. 8. Do not allow any breath to enter through the left nostril. 9. Maintain a fine flow of breath through the right nostril, synchronizing it with the movements of the chest. 10. When the lungs are full, block the right nostril completely, without moving the septum or the left nostril. 11. Hold the breath for a second or two to prepare and adjust the fingers for exhalation. 12. Exhale slowly and steadily through the left nostril, synchronizing the flow of out-breath with the gradual release of the extension and expansion of the rib-cage. 13. When the lungs feel completely empty, hold the breath for a second to prepare and adjust the fingers for inhalation through the left nostril. 14. Block the right nasal passage without disturbing the septum or the passage on the left, and narrow the left passage. 15. Now inhale through the left nostril as described in Paras 3 and 6 above, but reading the word 'right' for 'left' and vice versa. 16. When the lungs are full, block the left nostril completely, without disturbing the septum or the passage on the right. 17. Hold the breath for a second or two as in Para. 8 above. 18. Exhale through the right nostril as described in Para. 9 above. 19. See that no breath escapes through the left nostril. 20. When the lungs feel completely empty, hold the breath for a second or two, to prepare and re-adjust the fingers for inhalation, then repeat from Para. 3 above. 21. The cycle commences at (b) and ends at (e). 23. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes ending with inhalation through the right nostril. 24. Then lie in Savasana.

column11: 1. Sit in any asana following the techniques given in Paras 1 to 7 of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Bring the right hand to the nostrils and narrow both the nasal passages with the thumb, ring, and little fingers and exhale through both nostrils narrowly closed. 3. Inhale, following the techniques of Paras 3 and 4 of Stage Ia above. 4. Exhale, following the techniques of Paras 5 and 6 of Stage Ia. 5. When the lungs feel empty, block both nostrils and do external retention with uddiyana for fifteen seconds, or for as long as you can. 6. Release the uddiyana grip, readjust the fingers and follow the processes of inhalation and exhalation described in Paras 3 and 4 above. 7. Repeat an external retention with uddiyana. 8. The sequence of breath is: (a) exhale deeply through both nostrils; (b) breathe in through both passages; (c) out through both; (d) external retention with uddiyana; (e) breathe in through both passages; (f) out through both; (g) external retention with uddiyana; and so on. 9. One inhalation, one exhalation, and one external retention with uddiyana complete one cycle of this stage. 10. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes, ending with inhalation. 11. Then lie down in Savasana.

205 / Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma
Technique

Follow the technique given in paras 1 to 8 of Sūrya Bhedana Prānāyāma. (Image 599)

Empty the lungs completely through the right nostril. Control the aperture of the right nostril with the inner side of the right thumb, away from the nail.

Now inhale slowly, steadily and deeply through the right nostril, controlling the aperture with the tip of the right thumb near the nail. Fill the lungs to the brim (pūraka). During this inhalation the left nostril is completely blocked by the ring and little fingers.

After full inhalation, block the right nostril completely with the pressure of the thumb and release the pressure of the ring and little fingers on the left nostril. Readjust them on the outer edge of the left nostril and keep it parallel to the septum. Exhale slowly, steadily and deeply through the left nostril. Empty the lungs completely. The pressure should be exerted from the inner sides of the tips of the ring and little fingers (away from the nails) (rechaka).

After full exhalation through the left nostril, change the pressure on it by adjusting the fingers. In the changed position, the tips of the ring and little fingers nearer the nails exert the pressure.

Now inhale through the left nostril slowly, steadily and deeply, filling the lungs to the brim (pūraka).

After full inhalation through the left nostril, block it and exhale through the right nostril, adjusting the pressure of the right thumb on the right nostril as stated in para. 2 above (rechaka).

This completes one cycle of Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma. Here the rhythm of breathing is as follows: a. Exhale through the right nostril. b. Inhale through the right nostril. c. Exhale through the left nostril. d. Inhale through the left nostril. e. Exhale through the right nostril. f. Inhale through the right nostril. g. Exhale through the left nostril. h. Inhale through the left nostril. i. Exhale through the right nostril. j. Inhale through the right nostril ... and so on.

Stage (a) above is the preparatory one. The first real Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma cycle starts at stage (b) and ends at stage (e). The second cycle starts at stage (f) and ends at stage (i). Stage (j) is the safety measure to be observed after the completion of the cycles in order to prevent gasping, breathlessness and strain on the heart.

column11: 1. Sit in any asana, following the techniques given in Paras 1 to 7 of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained before and inhale, following the techniques given in Paras 3 to 6 of Stage Ib. 3. When the lungs are full, block the right nostril and hold the breath for a second as explained in Paras 7 and 8 of Stage IIb. 4. Exhale through the left nostril as described in Para. 9 of Stage Ib. 5. No breath should escape through the right nostril. 6. When the lungs feel empty, block both nostrils and do external retention with uddiyana for fifteen seconds, or for as long as you can. 7. Release the uddiyana grip, block the right nostril, and readjust the fingers for inhalation through the left. 8. Narrow the passage of the left nostril and inhale slowly, softly, and smoothly. 9. When the lungs are full, readjust the fingers. 10. Block the left nostril and exhale through the right. 11. When the lungs feel empty, block both nostrils, and do external retention with uddiyana for fifteen seconds, or for the same length of time as before. 12. Release the uddiyana grip. 13. Readjust the fingers for inhalation through the right nostril, blocking the left completely and repeat the sequence. 14. The cycle starts at (b) and ends at (g). 16. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes starting with exhalation and ending with inhalation through the right nostril. 17. Then lie down in Savasana.

column11: 1. Sit in any asana following the techniques given in Paras 1 to 4 of Stage Ia above. 2. When the lungs are completely full, block both nostrils and do internal retention with mula bandha for twenty seconds. 3. Readjust the fingers for exhalation, and exhale following the technique given in Para 5 of Stage Ia. 4. When the lungs feel empty, block both nostrils. 5. Do external retention with uddiyana for fifteen seconds. 6. Release the uddiyana grip and inhale as in Para 3. 7. The breath sequence is as follows: (a) exhale through both nostrils; (b) breathe in through both nostrils; (c) internal retention with mula bandha; (d) breathe out through both nostrils; (e) external retention with uddiyana; breathe in through both nostrils; and so on. 8. The cycle commences at (b) and ends at (e). 9. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes, ending with inhalation. 10. Then lie in Savasana.

column11: 1. Sit in any asana following the techniques given in Paras 1 to 7 of Stage Ib, keeping the left nostril blocked. 2. When the lungs are completely full, block both nostrils and do internal retention with mula bandha for twenty, twenty-five, or thirty seconds. 3. Readjust the fingers for exhalation; block the right nostril and keep the left narrow. 4. Exhale through the left nostril, making the passage as narrow as you can, following the technique of Para. 9 of Stage Ib. 5. When the lungs feel empty, block both nostrils and do external retention with uddiyana for fifteen seconds. 6. Release the uddiyana grip, and readjust the fingers for inhalation. 7. Block the right nostril and narrow the left. 8. Inhale slowly, softly, and smoothly through the left. 9. When the lungs are completely full, block both nostrils and do internal retention with mula bandha for twenty to thirty seconds. 10. Prepare for exhalation and readjust the fingers. 11. Block the left nostril. 12. Release the grip of the thumb-tip and narrow the right nostril. 13. Exhale until the lungs are empty. 14. When the lungs feel empty, block both nostrils and do external retention with uddiyana for fifteen seconds. 15. Release the uddiyana grip and readjust the fingers for inhalation. 16. Block the left nostril and inhale through the right as described in Para. 3 above, and continue in the same way. 17. The breath sequence is: (a) exhale through the right nostril; (b) breathe in through the right nostril; (c) internal retention with mula bandha; breathe out through the left nostril; (e) external retention with uddiyana; in through the left nostril; (g) internal retention with mula bandha; (h) out through the right nostril; external retention with uddiyana; through the right nostril, and so on. 18. The cycle in this stage commences at (b) and ends with (i). 19. Repeat for ten to fifteen minutes, ending with inhalation through the right nostril. 20. Then lie down in Savasana.

column10:
206 / Bhastrikā Prānāyāma
The technique is given in two stages here.

Technique: Stage I

Follow the technique in paras 1 and 2 of Ujjayi.

Take a fast, vigorous breath and exhale fast and forcefully. One inhalation and one exhalation completes a cycle of Bhastrikā. The sound made resembles air rushing through bellows.

Complete at a stretch 10 to 12 cycles. Then take a slow deep breath as in Ujjayi. Retain the breath with Mūla Bandha for 2 to 3 seconds, then exhale slowly and deeply as in Ujjayi.

This Ujjayi type of breathing rests the lungs and the diaphragm and prepares them for fresh cycles of Bhastrikā.

Repeat the cycles of Bhastrikā three to four times with Ujjayi breathing in between.

If the sound of the air lessens, and the vigour diminishes, then reduce their number.

After completion lie down in Savasana. (Image 592)

Technique: Stage II

Follow the technique in paras 1 and 2 of Ujjayi.

Adjust the thumb and finger pressure on the nostrils as explained in the technique of Sūrya Bhedana.

Close the left nostril completely but keep the right nostril partially open.

Inhale and exhale vigorously only through the right nostril for 10 to 12 cycles of Bhastrikā as in Stage I above.

Close the right nostril. Open the left nostril partially and repeat Bhastrikā for an equal number of cycles.

Release the fingers from the nostrils.

Take a few deep breaths as in Ujjayi.

Repeat the cycles on both sides three or four times, doing Ujjayi in between.

After completion lie down in Savasana. (Image 592)
column11: 1. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques given in Paras of ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 3. Take a short, strong breath and expel it with a quick strong blast. 4. Repeat this and you will find the second in-breath quicker and more forceful than the first one due to the forceful character of the preceding out-breath. 5. One quick in and out breath, taken together, completes one blast of bhastrika. 6. Do four to eight such blasts at a stretch to complete one cycle, ending with an out-breath. 7. Now take a few slow and deep breaths as in ujjayi, or if you wish you may hold your breath within, with mula bandha, for five to eight seconds. 8. Then exhale slowly and deeply as in ujjayi. 9. Repeat cycles of bhastrika blasts interspersed with ujjayi, with or without retention, three or four times. 10. Then take a deep breath and lie in savasana.

column11: 1. Both nostrils are kept partially closed throughout. 2. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques of Paras of ujjayi, Stage V. 3. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 4. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 in Ch. 22 on digital pranayama. 5. Partially close both nostrils with the tips of the thumb, ring, and little fingers. Make sure that both sides of each nostril are even. 6. Now perform bhastrika blasts following the techniques given in Paras 1 to 7 of Stage I above. 7. Repeat five or six times, take a few deep breaths, then lie in savasana.

column11: 1. Bhastrika is done through alternate nostrils, with interspersion of ujjayi breaths. 2. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques given in Paras of ujjayi, Stage V. 3. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 4. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 of Ch. 22 on digital pranayama. 5. With the help of digital control, block the left nostril completely and the right one partially. 6. Inhale and exhale through the right nostril vigorously, doing four to eight blasts at a stretch making sure the pressure is the same with each blast. 7. See that no breath escapes from the left nostril and end with a blast of out-breath. 8. Now block the right nostril, partially open the left and breathe vigorously through it with the same number of blasts as on the right and keeping the same pressure for each blast. 9. See that no breath escapes from the right nostril. End the blast with an out-breath. 10. These two together complete one cycle of Stage III. 11. Repeat them on both sides three or four times, take a few deep breaths, and then lie in savasana. 12. If you cannot do several cycles at a stretch, then after each cycle take a few breaths as in ujjayi to rest the lungs.

column11: 1. In stage III one cycle of bhastrika blasts is done through the right nostril, the other from the left. 2. In this stage, the in and out blasts are done through alternate nostrils; that is, if the in-breath is done from the right, then the out-breath is from the left and then the other way round. 3. Four or five such blasts form one half-cycle. 4. The other one starts with an in-breath from the left and is followed by an out-breath from the right, with an equal number of blasts. 5. These two make one cycle of Stage IV. 6. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques given in Paras of ujjayi, Stage V. 7. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 8. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 in Ch. 22 on digital pranayama. 9. Block the left nostril, half-open the right and take a quick strong in-breath through it. 10. Quickly close the right nostril, half-open the left and breathe out quickly and vigorously through it. 11. Do four or five blasts in quick succession. This forms the first half-cycle. 12. Now do the other half-cycle, repeating the same procedure as above, but breathing in from the left and out through the right. 13. This completes the second half-cycle. Do an equal number of blasts as above, maintaining the same rhythm, tone, and volume throughout. 14. Do three to four such full cycles, take a few breaths of ujjayi to rest the lungs, and then rest in savasana.

column10:
207. Kapālabhāti Prānāyāma
The process or kriya of Kapālabhāti (kapāla = skull; bhāti = light, lustre) is a milder form of Bhastrikā Prānāyāma. In Kapālabhāti, the inhalation is slow but the exhalation is vigorous. There is a split second of retention after each exhalation.

Do a few cycles of Kapālabhāti instead of Bhastrikā if the latter breathing proves too strenuous. Lie down in Savasana after finishing Kapālabhāti. (Image 592)

Effects Both Bhastrikā and Kapālabhāti activate and invigorate the liver, spleen, pancreas and abdominal muscles. Thus digestion is improved, the sinuses are drained, the eyes feel cool and one has a general sense of exhilaration.

Caution

As a locomotive engine is stoked with coal to generate steam to pull the train, so Bhastrikā generates prāna to activate the entire body. Too much stoking burns out the boiler of the engine. So also too long a practice of Bhastrikā wears out the system as the breathing process is forceful.

Persons with a weak constitution and poor lung capacity should not attempt Bhastrikā or Kapālabhāti.

Those suffering from ear or eye complaints (pus in the ear, detachment of the retina or glaucoma) should not attempt them either.

Nor should persons with high or low blood pressure.

If the nose starts to bleed or the ears to throb and ache, immediately stop Bhastrikā or Kapālabhāti.

Do not practise either for some time.
column11: Kapalabhati, sometimes referred to as a pranayama or a kriya, involves slow inhalation and vigorous exhalation. The term 'kapala' means skull and 'bhati' means light or luster. This technique is similar to bhastrika but milder. It includes a split second of retention after each exhalation. Kapalabhati can be divided into stages similar to bhastrika and practiced accordingly.
column12: Do kapalabhati instead of bhastrika if the latter proves too strenuous.
column13: Kapalabhati is similar to bhastrika but milder. It involves slow inhalation and vigorous exhalation, with a split second of retention after each out-breath.

column10:
208 / Bhramari Pranayama
Technique

Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. (This is the Jalandhara Bandha.)

Stretch the arms out straight and rest the back of the wrists on the knees. Join the tips of the index fingers to the tips of the thumbs, keeping the other fingers extended. (This position or gesture of the hand is known as the Jñāna Mudra, the symbol or seal of knowledge. The index finger symbolises the individual soul and the thumb the Universal Soul. The union of the two symbolises knowledge.)

Close the eyes and look inwards. (Image 597)

Exhale completely.

Inhalation (Pūraka): Take a slow, deep steady breath through both nostrils. The passage of the incoming air is felt on the roof of the palate and makes a sibilant sound (sa). This sound should be heard. Fill the lungs up to the brim. Care should be taken not to bloat the abdomen in the process of inhalation.

The entire abdominal area from the pubes up to the breast-bone should be pulled back towards the spine.

Retention (Antara Kumbhaka): Hold the breath for a second or two. Observe Mūla Bandha as described on p. 366.

Exhalation (Rechaka): Exhale slowly, deeply and steadily, until the lungs are completely empty. As you begin to exhale, keep your grip on the abdomen. After two or three seconds of exhalation, relax the diaphragm gradually and slowly.

Note: Unlike standard Ujjayi, during this exhalation, a soft humming sound like the murmuring of bees is made.

Wait (Bāhya Kumbhaka): Wait for a second before drawing a fresh breath.

Repeat the cycles for 5 to 10 minutes keeping the eyes closed throughout.

Lie on the floor in Savasana. (Image 592)

Effects The soft humming sound produced during exhalation is helpful in treating cases of insomnia. (As this practice is based on Ujjayi, it also soothes the nerves and tones the entire system).
column11: 1. Perform deep inhalations as in Ujjayi Pranayama. 2. Perform deep exhalations with a humming or murmuring sound. 3. Do not hold the breath (kumbhakas) in this pranayama. 4. Bhramari may also be done while performing Sanmukhi Mudra without Jalandhara Bandha.

column11: 1. Raise the hands to the face and the elbows to the level of the shoulders. 2. Place the thumb-tips in the ear-holes to keep out external sounds. 3. If the thumb-tips cause pain, reduce the pressure or push the tragi over the ear-holes and press them. 4. Close the eyes. 5. Bring the fore and middle fingers over the eyelids. 6. Draw the upper lids down with the pads of the middle finger-tips and cover the remaining space above it with the pads of the forefinger tips to keep out the light. 7. Keep the eye-balls passive and receptive and press them gently with the fingers. 8. Press the nostrils with the ring finger-tips to narrow the nasal passages for slow, steady, rhythmic and subtle breathing. 9. Keep the little fingers on the upper lips to feel the flow of breath. 10. The practitioner can hear the inner sound as the ears are closed by the thumbs. 11. Through pressure on the eye-balls, various colors of dazzling light may be seen; sometimes steady like that of the sun. 12. If it is difficult to hold Sanmukhi Mudra, then wrap cloth around the head and over the ears and temples. 13. After completing the practice of Bhramari Pranayama, inhale, then perform Savasana.

column10:
209 / Sitali Pranayama
Technique
Sit in Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid and the head level. Perform the Jnana Mudra with the hands (see p. 362, para. 21). Here Jalandhara Bandha is not done during inhalation but later.

Open the mouth and form the lips into an ‘O’.

The sides and tip of the tongue touching the teeth, from the molars to the front teeth, should be lifted and curled up. The shape of the tongue will resemble a fresh curled leaf about to open. (Image 601)

Protrude the curled tongue out of the lips. Draw in the air past the curled tongue with a sibilant sound (sssssssa) to fill the lungs completely. The air is drawn in as if through a pipette or a drinking straw. After full inhalation withdraw the tongue and close the mouth.

After full inhalation, lower the head, from the nape of the neck, to the trunk. The chin should rest in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. The head is now in the Jalandhara Bandha position.

Now hold the breath (antara kumbhaka) for about 5 seconds, practising Mula Bandha (see p. 366).

Exhale slowly with an aspirate sound (hhuuuuuuuum) through the nose as in Ujjayi.

This completes one cycle of Sitali Pranayama.

Lift the head and repeat the cycle for 5 to 10 minutes.

After completion lie down in Savasana. (Image 592)
Cools the system, soothes eyes and ears. Beneficial for low fever, biliousness, and thirst. Activates liver and spleen; improves digestion. Caution: High BP patients should omit retention. Heart patients should avoid.
column11: 1. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques given in Paras of Ujjayi, Stage. 2. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 3. Keep the head level. 4. Open the mouth and form the lips into an O. 5. Push out the tongue and curl it lengthwise so that its shape resembles a fresh curled leaf about to open. 6. Stretch the curled tongue further out and draw in air through it as if drinking with a straw, and fill the lungs completely. 7. After a full in-breath, withdraw the tongue and close the mouth. 8. Lower the head and perform Jalandhara Bandha. 9. Hold the breath for five to ten seconds, with or without Mula Bandha. 10. Exhale as in Ujjayi. 11. Repeat for five to ten minutes at a stretch. 12. At the end of the last one, inhale normally through both nostrils and then lie in Savasana.

column11: 1. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques given in Paras to 7 of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 3. Now inhale, following all the techniques in Paras of Stage above and ending with Mula Bandha. 4. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 of Ch. 22 on digital pranayama. 5. Partially close both nostrils with the tips of the thumb, the ring, and little fingers, keeping the pressure even on both nostrils so that the walls of the nasal passages remain parallel to the septum. 6. Exhale slowly, steadily, and completely, without strain. 7. Adjust the fingers on the nostrils delicately to control the volume and to regulate the flow of the out-breath evenly on both sides. 8. When the lungs feel completely empty, lower the hand and rest it on the knee. 9. Repeat for five to ten minutes. 10. At the end of the last cycle, inhale normally through both nostrils, then lie down in Savasana.

column11: 1. Sit in any comfortable position, following the techniques given in Paras of Ujjayi, Stage. 2. Exhale deeply. 3. Now inhale, following the techniques in Paras of Stage above and ending with internal retention and Mula Bandha. 4. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 of Ch. 22 on digital pranayama. 5. Block the left nostril completely, partially close the right and exhale slowly, steadily, and completely through it without straining. 6. When the lungs feel completely empty, lower the hand and rest it on the knee. 7. Inhale again, as in Paras Stage. 8. Bring the right hand to the nose and block the right nostril completely, partially close the left one and exhale slowly, steadily, and completely without straining. 9. Then lower the hand. 10. Repeat for five to ten minutes. 11. At the end of the last cycle, inhale normally with open nostrils, then lie down in Savasana.

column10:
210 / Sītkāri Prānāyāma
Technique

Sit in Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid and the head level. Perform the Jñāna Mudra with the hands (see p. 362, para. 21). Here Jalandhara Bandha is not done during inhalation but later.

Mouth Position: Keep the tongue flat as in its normal state. The lips are kept slightly parted and only the tip of the tongue protrudes between the teeth. (Note: The tongue is not curled as in Sītalī).

Inhalation (Pūraka): Draw in the air through the mouth past the tongue with a sibilant sound (sssssssa) to fill the lungs completely.

After full inhalation, withdraw the tongue and close the mouth.

Lower the head, from the nape of the neck, to the trunk. The chin should rest in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. The head is now in the Jalandhara Bandha position.

Retention (Antara Kumbhaka): Now hold the breath for about 5 seconds, practising Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Exhalation (Rechaka): Exhale slowly with an aspirate sound (hhuuuuuuuum) through the nose as in Ujjayi.

This completes one cycle of Sītkāri Prānāyāma.

Lift the head and repeat the cycle for 5 to 10 minutes.

After completion lie down in Savasana. (Image 592)

Effects Has the same cooling effects as Sītalī: it cools the system, soothes the eyes and ears, and acts as a beneficial aid for low fever, biliousness, and thirst. It activates the liver and spleen and improves digestion.

Caution

High Blood Pressure: This technique may cause greater strain for high blood pressure patients than Sītalī. Patients with high blood pressure should omit retention (kumbhaka).

Heart Conditions: Heart patients should avoid this practice.
column11: Sitakari is a variation of Sitali Pranayama. It is also called Sitakari Pranayama as the breath is drawn with a hissing sound between the two lips. Follow the same techniques and stages as Sitali, but without curling the tongue. The lips are kept slightly apart and the tip of the tongue protrudes only slightly, but is kept flat. Sitakari, like Sitali, is performed in three stages, following the same techniques as in all stages of Sitali.

column10:
211 / Sama Vrtti Pranayama
Sama means the same or identical, straight, entire, whole and complete: also similarly or in the same manner.

Vrtti means action, movement, function or operation, a course of conduct or method.

In Sama Vrtti Pranayama, therefore, an attempt is made to achieve uniformity in the duration of all the three processes of breathing, namely, puraka or inhalation, kumbhaka or retention, and rechaka or exhalation in any type of pranayama. If one lasts 5 seconds so do the others.

This uniformity of 5 seconds should be maintained throughout all cycles of breathing in any type of Pranayama like Ujjayi, Surya Bhedana, Nadi Sodhana, Sitali and so on.

Caution 5. In the beginning Sama Vrtti Pranayama should be confined only to inhalation (puraka) and exhalation (rechaka). 6. First, achieve uniformity of length of time in puraka and rechaka then only attempt antara kumbhaka (retention of breath after full inhalation). 7. Start the antara kumbhaka gradually. In the beginning, the ratio time for puraka, antara kumbhaka and rechaka should be kept at 1 : 1/2 : 1. 8. Very slowly increase the proportions to 1 : 3/4 : 1. After this is firmly established attempt 1 : 1 : 1. Only after mastering this, increase the proportion of antara kumbhaka so as to achieve the ratio of 1 : 1 : 1. 9. Do not attempt bahya kumbhaka (restraint of breath after full exhalation) until you have achieved the desired ratio of 1 : 1 : 1 in puraka, antara kumbhaka and rechaka. 10. If all air is expelled from the lungs, the vacuum inside and the atmospheric pressure outside will create a tremendous strain upon the lungs. Therefore, in the beginning, do not do both antara kumbhaka and bahya kumbhaka together. 11. Practise antara kumbhaka and bahya kumbhaka separately or alternately. It is beneficial to practise kumbhakas first by interspersing them after two or three cycles of deep breathing with puraka and rechaka alone. For example do two or three cycles of deep breathing and one cycle of antara kumbhaka. Then do two or three cycles of deep breathing followed by one cycle of bahya kumbhaka. Start with 3 antara kumbhakas and 3 bahya kumbhakas, and increase the number of kumbhakas very gradually.

After this is firmly established attempt 1 : 1 : 1. Only after mastering this, increase the proportion of antara kumbhaka so as to achieve the ratio of 1 : 1 : 1. 9. Do not attempt bahya kumbhaka (restraint of breath after full exhalation) until you have achieved the desired ratio of 1 : 1 : 1 in puraka, antara kumbhaka and rechaka. 10. Therefore, in the beginning, do not do both antara kumbhaka and bahya kumbhaka together. 11. Practise antara kumbhaka and bahya kumbhaka separately or alternately. It is beneficial to practise kumbhakas first by interspersing them after two or three cycles of deep breathing with puraka and rechaka alone. For example do two or three cycles of deep breathing and one cycle of antara kumbhaka. Then do two or three cycles of deep breathing followed by one cycle of bahya kumbhaka. Start with 3 antara kumbhakas and 3 bahya kumbhakas, and increase the number of kumbhakas very gradually.
Establishes uniformity in the duration of inhalation, retention, and exhalation; trains the lungs to handle vacuum and pressure without strain; prepares the mind for concentration (dharana) and meditation.

212 / Visama Vrtti Pranayama
Visama means among many other things irregular and difficult.

Visama Vrtti Pranayama is so called because the same length of time for inhalation, retention and exhalation is not maintained. This leads to interruption of rhythm and the difference in ratio creates difficulty and danger for the pupil.

In this type of pranayama if full inhalation takes 5 seconds, the breath is held (antara kumbhaka) for 20 seconds, and exhalation takes 10 seconds, the ratio being 1 : 4 : 2. At first the pupil will find it hard to maintain the rhythm during exhalation, but it all eases with practice.

Conversely, if inhalation is for 10 seconds, the breath is held for 20 seconds and exhalation takes 5 seconds, the ratio here being 2 : 4 : 1.

Again if the length of time can be so varied that if inhalation is for 20 seconds, retention is for 10 seconds and the exhalation for 5, the ratio being 4 : 2 : 1.

In one cycle of pranayama, one can adopt the ratios 1 : 2 : 4, 2 : 4 : 1, and 4 : 1 : 2. Then these three ratios are counted as one cycle of pranayama.

If bahya kumbhaka (restraint after full exhalation and before fresh inhalation) is also observed, the combination of ratios will be greater still.

If the different ratios are observed in the Viloma, Anuloma and Pratiloma methods of pranayama (described below) in the basic varieties of pranayamas like Ujjayi, Surya Bhedana, Nadi Sodhana, Bhramari, Sitali and Sitakari, the number of combinations will be astronomical.

No mortal could perform all these different combinations in one lifetime.

The path of Visama Vrtti Pranayama is fraught with danger. Do not, therefore, dream of attempting to practise it on your own without the personal supervision of an experienced Guru or teacher.

Due to disharmony caused by these different time ratios for inhalation, retention and exhalation, all the systems of the body, especially the respiratory and nervous ones, are overtaxed and unduly strained.

The caution given on Sama Vrtti Pranayama (see p. 381), regarding the practice of kumbhaka in paragraphs 5 to 10, applies with greater force in Visama Vrtti Pranayama.

One now begins to realise the truth of Svatmarama’s statement in the second chapter of the Hatha Yoga Pradipika: ‘Prana should be tamed more slowly and more gradually than lions, elephants and tigers (according to one’s capacities and physical limitations); otherwise it will kill the practitioner.’

213 / Viloma Prānāyāma
Technique The technique is given below in two stages, which are distinct.

Technique: Stage I (Interrupted Inhalation)

Viloma Prānāyāma can be done either in a sitting posture or while lying down.

If done when seated, keep the back erect, lower the head to the trunk so that the chin rests in the notch between the collar-bones on the top of the breastbone. This is Jalandhara Bandha. Keep the hands in Jñāna Mudra (see p. 362, para. 21).

Inhalation (Pūraka): Inhale for 2 seconds, pause for 2 seconds holding the breath, again inhale for 2 seconds, again pause for 2 seconds holding the breath, and continue like this until the lungs are completely full.

During the pauses in the process of inhalation Mūla Bandha should be practised.

Retention (Antara Kumbhaka): Now hold the breath for 5 to 10 seconds according to capacity, practising Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Exhalation (Rechaka): Exhale slowly and deeply as in Ujjayi with an aspirate sound (huuuum). During exhalation relax the Mūla Bandha.

This completes one cycle of the first stage of Viloma Prānāyāma.

Repeat 10 to 15 cycles of this first stage at a stretch.

Technique: Stage II (Interrupted Exhalation)

Rest for a minute or two.

Inhalation (Pūraka): Then take a deep breath without any pauses as in Ujjayi with a sibilant sound (sssssssa), keeping the chin on the top of the breast-bone. Fill the lungs completely.

Retention (Antara Kumbhaka): Hold the breath from 5 to 10 seconds, keeping the Mūla Bandha grip.

Exhalation (Rechaka): Exhale for 2 seconds and pause for 2 seconds. Again exhale for 2 seconds, pause for 2 seconds and continue like this until the lungs are completely emptied.

During the pauses maintain the Mūla Bandha grip.

This completes one cycle of the second stage of Viloma Prānāyāma.

Repeat the second stage of Viloma 10 to 15 times at a stretch.

This completes Viloma Prānāyāma.

Then lie down in Savasana. (Image 592)

Effects

Stage I helps those with low blood pressure.

Stage II (lying down) benefits those with high blood pressure.

Caution

High Blood Pressure: Patients with high blood pressure should only do Stage II lying down.

Heart Conditions: Heart patients must master Nāḍī Śodhana first before attempting Viloma.
column11: 1. Lie quietly for a few minutes as in Ujjayi Stage I, preferably using planks or cushions. 2. Follow the techniques given in Paras 2, 3, and 4 of Ujjayi Stage II, and exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 3. Start with interrupted inhalation: Inhale for two or three seconds; pause, and hold the breath for two or three seconds and do this again. 4. To pause, the diaphragm is lightly immobilized. 5. When you breathe in again, do not let the diaphragm loose after each pause. 6. Continue in this way until the lungs are completely full, which may involve four or five pauses. 7. No strain should be felt throughout the practice. 8. Exhale slowly and deeply, as in Ujjayi Stage II, gradually releasing the grip of the diaphragm. 9. This completes one cycle of Viloma Stage I. 10. Repeat them for seven to ten minutes, or for as long as you do not feel fatigue; breathe normally two or three times, then rest in Savasana.

column11: 1. Lie quietly for a few minutes as in Ujjayi Stage I. 2. Follow the techniques given in Paras 2, 3, and 4 of Ujjayi Stage II. 3. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 4. Take a long deep breath without any pause, as in Ujjayi, filling the lungs completely, but do not over-strain. 5. Exhale for two or three seconds; pause, hold the breath for two or three seconds and repeat. 6. Continue in this way until the lungs feel completely emptied, which may involve four or five pauses. 7. Gradually release the grip on the abdomen. 8. This completes one cycle of Viloma Stage II. 9. Repeat them for seven to ten minutes or for as long as fatigue is not felt. 10. Inhale; then do Savasana.

Technique: Stage I (Interrupted Inhalation)

Viloma Prānāyāma can be done either in a sitting posture or while lying down.

If done when seated, keep the back erect, lower the head to the trunk so that the chin rests in the notch between the collar-bones on the top of the breastbone. This is Jalandhara Bandha. Keep the hands in Jñāna Mudra (see p. 362, para. 21).

Inhalation (Pūraka): Inhale for 2 seconds, pause for 2 seconds holding the breath, again inhale for 2 seconds, again pause for 2 seconds holding the breath, and continue like this until the lungs are completely full.

During the pauses in the process of inhalation Mūla Bandha should be practised.

Retention (Antara Kumbhaka): Now hold the breath for 5 to 10 seconds according to capacity, practising Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Exhalation (Rechaka): Exhale slowly and deeply as in Ujjayi with an aspirate sound (huuuum). During exhalation relax the Mūla Bandha.

This completes one cycle of the first stage of Viloma Prānāyāma.

Repeat 10 to 15 cycles of this first stage at a stretch.

Technique: Stage II (Interrupted Exhalation)

Rest for a minute or two.

Inhalation (Pūraka): Then take a deep breath without any pauses as in Ujjayi with a sibilant sound (sssssssa), keeping the chin on the top of the breast-bone. Fill the lungs completely.

Retention (Antara Kumbhaka): Hold the breath from 5 to 10 seconds, keeping the Mūla Bandha grip.

Exhalation (Rechaka): Exhale for 2 seconds and pause for 2 seconds. Again exhale for 2 seconds, pause for 2 seconds and continue like this until the lungs are completely emptied.

During the pauses maintain the Mūla Bandha grip.

This completes one cycle of the second stage of Viloma Prānāyāma.

Repeat the second stage of Viloma 10 to 15 times at a stretch.

This completes Viloma Prānāyāma.

Then lie down in Savasana. (Image 592)

Effects

Stage I helps those with low blood pressure.

Stage II (lying down) benefits those with high blood pressure.

Caution

High Blood Pressure: Patients with high blood pressure should only do Stage II lying down.

Heart Conditions: Heart patients must master Nāḍī Śodhana first before attempting Viloma.

Start interrupted exhalation, following the techniques given in Para. 3 of Stage II above, gradually releasing the grip on the diaphragm. 6. This completes one cycle of Viloma Stage III. 7. column10:
214 / Anuloma Pranayama
Technique
Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk and rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breastbone. (This is the Jalandhara Bandha.)

Inhale deeply through both nostrils as in Ujjayi until the lungs are fully filled.

Hold the breath after inhalation (antara kumbhaka) from 5 to 10 seconds according to capacity, maintaining Mula Bandha (see p. 366).

Bring the right hand to the nose as described in Surya Bhedana Pranayama, relax the Mula Bandha and exhale slowly from the partially opened right nostril, keeping the left one completely blocked. Completely empty the lungs and then lower the hand.

Inhale through both nostrils, until the lungs are filled as in para. 3.

Hold the breath after inhalation (antara kumbhaka) from 5 to 10 seconds according to capacity, maintaining Mula Bandha. The retention of breath described in para. 4 and in this para. should be of equal length.

Again bring the right hand to the nose. Release the Mula Bandha and close the right nostril completely. Now keep the left nostril partially open, and exhale slowly and deeply to empty the lungs completely.

This completes one cycle of Anuloma Pranayama.

Do 5 to 8 cycles at a stretch.

Then lie down in Savasana. (Image 592)
Same effects as Ujjayi, Nadi Sodhana, and Surya Bhedana. Caution: Variation in rhythm (exhalation longer than inhalation) makes this difficult; only for advanced pupils. Hazardous for BP/heart/nervous disorders.
column11: 1. Sit in any asana, following the techniques given in Paras of ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs. 3. Inhale deeply through both nostrils until the lungs are full. 4. Hold the breath for a second or two to bring the right hand to the nostrils, as explained in Paras 12 to 22 of Ch. 22 on digital pranayama. 5. Partially open both nostrils with the tips of the thumb and fingers, making the inner walls of the nasal passages parallel to and equidistant from the septum. 6. Exhale slowly, carefully, and deeply, without using any force. 7. Keep the fingers firm and sensitive to adjust the nostrils and to monitor and equalize the volume of out-flow on each side. 8. When the lungs are completely empty, lower the right hand and rest it on the knee. 9. This completes one cycle. Repeat for fifteen to twenty minutes. 10. Inhale with open nostrils, then lie in Savasana.

column11: 1. Sit in any asana, following the technique given in Paras to 7 of ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Exhale. 3. Inhale, following the techniques given in Paras and 3. 4. Ensure no breath escapes through the right nostril. 15. When the lungs feel empty, lower the right hand and rest it on the knee. 16. This completes one cycle. Repeat for fifteen to twenty minutes. 17. Inhale, then lie in Savasana.

column10:
215 / Pratiloma Pranayama
Technique
Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. This is the Jalandhara Bandha.

Stretch the left arm. Rest the back of the left wrist on the left knee. Perform the Jnana Mudra with the left hand (see 203, 3).

Bend the right arm at the elbow, and the index and middle fingers towards the palm, keeping them passive. Bring the ring and little fingers towards the thumb. (Image 598)

Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose just below the nasal bone and the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose just below the nasal bone, just above the curve of the fatty tissue of the nostrils.

Press the ring and little fingers to block the left side of the nose completely.

With the right thumb, press the right side of the fatty tissue so as to make the outer edge of the nostril parallel to the lower edge of the cartilage of the septum.

The right thumb is bent at the top joint and the tip of the thumb is placed at a right angle to the septum. (Image 599)

Now inhale slowly and deeply, controlling the aperture of the right nostril with the tip of the thumb nearer the nail. Fill the lungs to the brim (puraka).

Then block the right nostril so that both the nostrils are now blocked.

Hold the breath for about 5 to 10 seconds (antara kumbhaka) and stay in Mula Bandha (see p. 366).

Lower the right hand. Release the Mula Bandha grip. Exhale slowly and deeply as in Ujjayi (203) until the lungs are completely empty.

Again raise the right hand to the nose. Inhale through the partially opened left nostril slowly and deeply, keeping the right nostril completely closed.

Fill the lungs to the brim.

Hold the breath with the Mula Bandha grip from 5 to 10 seconds. The retention of breath (antara kumbhaka) after inhalation from either nostril should be of equal duration.

Lower the right hand, release the Mula Bandha, exhale slowly and deeply, completely expelling all air from the lungs as in Ujjayi.

This completes one cycle of Pratiloma Pranayama.

Do 5 to 8 cycles at a stretch.

Then lie down in Savasana. (Image 592)
Same effects as Ujjayi, Nadi Sodhana, and Surya Bhedana. Caution: Difficult due to rhythm variation (inhalation longer than exhalation); only for advanced pupils. Hazardous for BP/heart/nervous disorders.
column11: 1. Sit in any asana, following the techniques given in Paras 1 to 7 of Ujjayi, Stage V. 2. Exhale. 3. Bring the right hand to the nostrils as explained in Paras 12 to 22 of Chapter 22 on digital pranayama. 4. Control both nostrils with the tips of the thumb and fingers, making the nasal passages as narrow as possible and parallel to the septum. 5. Keep an even pressure on both sides of the nostrils to make the two passages even in width. Do not disturb the septum. 6. Inhale slowly, carefully, and deeply, without using any force. 7. Feel the air as it enters the nasal passages. 8. Keep the fingers firm and sensitive, adjusting their tips evenly on both sides of the nostrils to observe, guide, and equalize the volume and the smooth inflow of air. 9. When the lungs are completely full, hold the breath for a second or two, then lower the right hand and rest it on the right knee. 10. Exhale with open nostrils slowly, steadily, and smoothly until the lungs feel completely empty. 11. This completes one cycle. Repeat the cycle for ten to fifteen minutes or for as long as you feel no strain. 12. After completing the last cycle, inhale with open nostrils, then lie in Savasana.
column12: If any strain is felt, stop practice for the day.

column10:
216 / Sahita and Kevala Kumbhaka Pranayama
Sahita means accompanied by, together with or associated with. When pranayama practices are observed with the intentional aid and deliberate accompaniment of bahya and antara kumbhaka, they are known as Sahita Kumbhaka Pranayamas.

Kevala means isolated, pure, absolute and perfect. When the practices of kumbhaka becomes instinctive, they are called Kevala Kumbhaka.

When the pupil has mastered Kevala Kumbhaka, he has isolated himself from the world and is in tune with the Infinite. He has obtained a measure of control over one of the most subtle and powerful of elements which can pervade the smallest crevice as well as the vast sky. His mind is completely absorbed with Prana and becomes as free as Prana itself.

As a wind drives smoke and impurities from the atmosphere, pranayama drives away the impurities of the body and the mind. Then, says Patanjali, the DIVINE FIRE within blazes forth in its full glory and the mind becomes fit for concentration (dharana) and meditation (dhyana). (Yoga Sutras, chapter II, 52 and 53.) This takes a long time. By degrees is the darkness banished by the dawn.
No technique steps provided.
-

217 / Jalandhara Bandha
1. Sit in a comfortable position like siddhasana, swastikasana, bhadrasana, virasana, baddhakonasana or padmasana (see Pls 10-14). 2. Keep the back erect. 3. Lift the sternum and the front part of the rib cage. 4. Without tensing, stretch the sides of the neck and move the shoulder blades into the body; keep the thoracic and cervical spine concave and bend the head forwards and downwards from the back of the neck towards the chest. Do not constrict the throat or strain the neck muscles. It should not be forced forward, downward or tensed back (Pls 55 and 56). 5. Keep the neck and throat muscles soft. 6. Bring the head down so that the point and both sides of the jaw-bone rest evenly in the notch between the collar-bones on the front wall of the chest (Pls 57 and 58). 7. Do not stretch the chin more to one side or the other (Pl. 59). 8. Also do not tilt the neck to one side (Pl. 60), which may cause pain and strain that continue for a long time. 9. As elasticity is gained, the neck bends down increasingly. 10. Do not force the chin to the chest as in Pl. 55, but lift the chest to meet the descending chin as in Pl. 58. 11. Keep the centre of the head and chin in alignment with the middle of the sternum, the navel and the perineum (Pl. 61). 12. Do not cave in the ribs, while resting the chin on the chest (Pl. 62). 13. Relax the temples and keep the eyes and ears passive (Pl. 57).

Do not constrict the lungs while the abdominal organs are compressed.
Do not squeeze the abdomen until the breath has been expelled.
If strain is felt on the temples or if the intake of breath is labored, this means that the uddiyana has been done beyond capacity.
Practice on an empty stomach only.
Never inhale until the grip of uddiyana is released and the abdominal organs are brought to their original relaxed state.

It is said to be the lion that kills the elephant named death.
It is the best of bandhas, and he who constantly practices it, as taught by his guru, becomes young again.
It exercises the diaphragm.
Through uddiyana bandha the great bird prana is forced to fly up through the sushumna nadi, the main channel for the flow of nervous energy, which is situated inside the spinal column (merudanda).

218 / Mula Bandha
### Stage I
1. Contract the muscles of the area between the anus and the genitals and lift them vertically towards the navel. 2. Simultaneously, press the lower anterior abdomen below the navel backwards and upwards towards the spine. 3. Change the downward course of apana vayu and make it flow up to unite with the prana vayu, which has its seat in the region of the chest. 4. Attempt mula bandha first in internal retention after inhalation (antarakumbhaka). 5. In mula bandha, only the perineal and lower abdominal area between the anus and navel is contracted, pulled back to the spine, and lifted up towards the diaphragm (PL 69). 6. Practice contracting the anal sphincter muscles (asvini mudra) to help master mula bandha.

Even the correct performance of mula bandha has its own dangers as it increases sexual retentive power, which the practitioner is tempted to abuse.
Improper performance of the former will cause involuntary discharge of semen and loss of vitality.
Improper performance of the latter will seriously weaken the practitioner, who will lack virility.
There is grave danger in attempting to learn the uddiyana and mula bandhas by oneself.

The lift of the diaphragm gently massages the muscles of the heart, thereby toning them.
It tones the abdominal organs, increases the gastric fire, and eliminates toxins in the digestive tract.
The practitioner acquires moral and spiritual power, which will shine forth like the sun.
With the mastery of the three bandhas, the yogi is at the crossroads of his destiny, one road leading to bhoga (the enjoyment of worldly pleasures) and the other to Yoga, union with the Supreme Soul.
The goal is the complete restraint or bandha of the chitta, which includes the mind (manas), the intellect (buddhi), and the ego (ahamkara).
While practicing mula bandha, the yogi attempts to reach the true source (mula) of all creation.
The yogi's senses are turned inwards to meet the Source of all Creation.

219 / Chandra Bhedana
This prAJ:tayama has been described in Yoga Chudama'!i Upanisad(95-97)
without mentioning the name chandra bhedana, but giving only the
method.
Chandra is the moon. In chandra bhedana pranayama all inhalauons are
done through the left nostril (Pl. 1 t 2) and all exhalations through the right
(Pl. 11 t). Pranic energy 10 alt inhalations is channelled through the Ida or
chandra nad1. All exhalauons pass through the pingala or SOrya nad1.
Chandra bhedana is done in four stages, similar to those of sorya
bhedana.

column11: 1. Meditation is the technique of inter-penetrating the five sheaths (kosas) of the Sadhaka to blend them into one harmonious whole. 2. The body is known as the city of Brahma (Brahmapuri) with nine gates. These gates are the eyes, ears, nostrils, mouth, anus, and the reproductive organ. Some add the navel and the crown of the head and say that the body has eleven gates. All these have to be closed in meditation. The city is controlled by the ten winds (vayus), five organs of perception (jnanendriyas), five organs of action (karmendriyas), and seven chakras or inner chambers. As pearls are strung together on a thread to make a necklace, so have the chakras to be connected to the self to make an integrated person. 3. In meditation, the brain has to be well balanced in relation to the spine. Any unevenness in its position disturbs the quietness of meditation. The energies of the left and the right hemispheres of the brain have to be brought to the center. The thinking activity of the brain ceases. Just as one withdraws energy from a particular limb or part of the body to make it passive, so also the flow of energy to the brain must be reduced and directed towards the heart - the seat of the soul. The key to the technique of meditation lies in keeping the brain as a passive observer.
column12: Ensure the body does not collapse during meditation to avoid intellectual dullness and a distracted mind.
column13: Meditation leads to the integration of body, mind, intelligence, will, consciousness, ego, and the self. It allows the practitioner to experience universality, timelessness, and fullness.

column11: 4. The various preparatory techniques of yama, niyama, asana, and pranayama mold the body and mind, pacify and balance them. In a steady and stable posture, free from physical and mental disturbances, an even circulation of arterial and venous blood, lymphatic and cerebro-spinal fluid is maintained through the head and spinal column. Stimulation is kept minimal and as symmetrical as possible. This evenness of circulation and stimulation allows the brain and mind to attain a unification of knowledge and experience. 5. The brain is divided into three main portions: the cerebral cortex, the hypothalamus, and the cerebellum. The cerebral cortex functions in the process of thinking, speech, memory, and imagination. The hypothalamus regulates the activities of the internal organs and imprints emotional reactions of pleasure and pain, joy and sorrow, contentment and disappointment. The cerebellum is the center of muscular coordination. The back brain is regarded as that which functions in meditation; it is the seat of wisdom and clarity.

column11: The Head: 13. Keep the crown of the head parallel to the ceiling without tilting the head to the right or the left, forwards or backwards, up or down. 14. If the head is down, the sadhaka is brooding on the past, the mind is dull and tamasic. If it moves up, he is wandering in the future, which is rajasic. When the head is held level, he is in the present, and this is a pure (sattvic) state of mind. Eyes and Ears: 15. Close the eyes and look within. Shut your ears to outward sounds. Listen to the inner vibrations and follow them until they merge in their source. Any absent-mindedness or lack of awareness in the eyes and ears creates fluctuations in the mind. The closure of the eyes and ears directs the sadhaka to meditate upon Him who is verily the eye of the eye, the ear of the ear, the speech of speech, the mind of the mind, and the life of life.

column11: 16. Flex the arms at the elbows, raise the hands and fold the palms in front of the chest with the thumbs pointing towards the sternum. This is called anjali or hrdayanjali mudra. 17. Intelligence oscillating between the head and the heart creates multiple thoughts. When the mind oscillates, press the palms to bring back the attention of the mind on the Self. If the pressure of the palms becomes loose, it is a sign that the mind is wandering. Again join them firmly to recollect the Self. 18. Dhyana is the integration of the body, mind, intelligence, will, consciousness, ego, and the self. The body is the external layer of the mind, mind of the intelligence, intelligence of the will, will of consciousness, consciousness of the 'I' or ego, and the 'I' of the pure Self (Atma). Dhyana is the process of inter-penetration of all these sheaths, a merging of all that is known into unknown, or of the finite into the Infinite. 19. The mind acts as the subject and the Self object; yet in reality, the Self is the subject. The end of meditation is to make the mind submerge in the Self so that all seeking and searching comes to an end. Then the sadhaka experiences his own universality, timelessness, and fullness. 20. Stay in meditation for as long as you can, without allowing the body to collapse. Then do savasana.
